39440948.review:
[h1]The Sexy Brutale: Groundhog Day Meets Ghost Detective Meets Gatsby[/h1]

The Sexy Brutale is a 3D point-and-click murder mystery, but with a twist. You investigate the murders of the various guests attending a masquerade party at the casino mansion, The Sexy Brutale…while they happen. Your job is not only to find out how the masked residents meet their gruesome demises, but also to save them. You play as a masked man, Lufcadio Boone, and are guided in your quest to stop these grisly murders by a mysterious specter, the Bloody Woman. The supernatural and mysterious are abound in the glitzy mansion, but the shine and spectacle hides a sinister plot by the menacing waitstaff.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The gameplay of The Sexy Brutale is a refreshing and interesting twist on the genre of point-and-click murder mysteries. You are not simply investigating murders, you investigate them as they are happening, and your goal is more than to find out what happened- it is to find out how to stop it from happening. To accomplish that, The Sexy Brutale has you playing out the premise of Groundhog Day- upon the clock striking 12am time is reset, and you begin the same day anew. But unlike Groundhog Day, you have the additional challenge that [i]you cannot interact with anyone directly[/i]. Attempting to do so will cause time to freeze, with the masks of the guests chasing you out of the room their owner currently stands in. You must learn the routine of the to-be victims, and interact with the surroundings to prevent the murders from being carried out. In this way, you have all the time you could ever need, and yet are racing against the clock to prevent the untimely ends of every guest in the mansion.
These mechanics result in a fantastic series of puzzles and thinking ahead, tracking guest and waitstaff movements, and determining not only how the murders were carried out but how to prevent them from occurring.

[b]Storytelling[/b]

The story of The Sexy Brutale is engaging and intriguing. Discovering the secrets of the casino mansion is exciting, and the plot constantly moves along with twists and turns that keep you wanting to learn more. Who is the ghostly Bloody Woman, and why does she want to help you? Who is the strange man in a gilded mask you keep grabbing glimpses of? Why is the waitstaff on this bloody rampage in the first place? What are all those noises you keep hearing throughout the day? What really is happening at the Sexy Brutale?

[b]Replay-ability[/b]

Admittedly, the Sexy Brutale does lack much replay-ability. There are 52 playing cards hidden throughout the mansion, and invitations for each ill-fated guest. Outside of these collectables, however, the game ends with the finishing of the tale of the Sexy Brutale- not particularly surprising given the game is a murder mystery.

[b]Visuals[/b]

The setting of the casino mansion The Sexy Brutale is stunning. The variety of rooms in the sprawling and extravagant manor keep the environments unique and engaging. The level of detail and diversity in all of these rooms is fantastic. Likewise, the character designs are just as fantastical. Each guest is fittingly excessive in their design, and each wear an elaborate mask that hints at their personality, from the clockwork mask of the tinkerer Reginald Sixpence to the macabre skull mask of the gothic Willow Blue. The waitstaff all appear menacingly identical in their matching gas mask and suit attire, and the fiery masks wailing if you approach is a disturbing sight.
However, one of my biggest qualms with the game is a visual one. The animations of the game are rather lackluster given the detail of everything else. Scripted animations feel extremely robotic given their pre-determined nature, and animations occasionally play incorrectly or cut short in such a way that characters often look stiff and unnatural. It’s not a huge issue, but one that bugged me throughout my playthrough.

[b]Level Design[/b]

As mentioned, the level design is wonderful. The combination of a casino and mansion makes for an outlandish, lavish setting that the story and gameplay fit perfectly into. The enormous number of rooms in the building each have stories to tell, and are packed with character and beauty, from the Pick Your Poison bar to the Main Stage.

[b]Sound Design[/b]

The sound design of The Sexy Brutale is also exceptional. The main theme alone is fantastic, a jazzy electro swing that sets an antiqued yet lively mood, fitting of a mansion that appears timeless and ancient. The music complements whatever setting your in-haunting, deep scores wear at your nerve as you creep through the basement; upbeat, swinging tracks lead you through the flashy casino, and dramatic, tension-filled pieces ready to explode sound impending doom for the masked guests.

[b]Overall[/b]

Overall, The Sexy Brutale delivers a unique and thrilling murder mystery. Its setting, visuals, and sounds meticulously ensure every second you spend in the Sexy Brutale is full of intrigue, bedazzlement, and tension as you work to save guests from gruesome murder and learn what is truly going on in the dark manor. The gameplay is engaging, unique, and fits the tone and style of the game perfectly. Outside of some minor issues of lag and animation troubles, the only complaint I can really voice about The Sexy Brutale is about it’s length- I need more!
I highly recommend the Sexy Brutale, but if you’re someone who only values games in the amount of playtime they provide over the quality of that playtime, I would suggest potentially waiting for a sale.

39422271.review:
It's not perfect, it's not long, but it's great.

The game may be technically simple in its puzzles, but the experience figuring them out is more than compensating. It is interesting learning how the mansion works, in particular learning the schedules of everyone. Each character follows a strict schedule during the day and knowing it is key to solving their murder. Puzzles never get complicated, but later chapters have more than one on the way to finding the murder and how to solve it.

The game is technically impressive in how each room has time dependent lightning and music. It also doesn't hurt that it looks and sounds good from an artistic perspective too.

However the game does have some flaws. Puzzles never get more complicated than one item in your inventory at a time and nearly never overlap. The story of the game is good, but pretty much dumped onto you in the final chapter. Expect no mid game reveals.

The mask powers you get as you save each guest are an interesting concept. But the powers are unsatisfying. They are shallow and you never need to think about them. You know instantly when to use them, if you even have a choice, and several guests don't offer any due to being saved along with another that does.

Yet, despite the flaws it is genuinely interesting wandering about the mansion and learning about it and its inhabitants. The act of exploring is a large part of the appeal here.

Overall the game is an interesting piece of tech with some okay puzzles. It's well worth the experience even if the gameplay is on the shallow side from a technical viewpoint.

39374715.review:
8 hours of gameplay, I still don't know what Brutale is?  Is it a combination of Brutal and Tale?  Is it a made up word?  Is it an alternate form of the word Brutal? Why is it Sexy? Ultimately these questions don't matter much, yet I still feel I should ask them because I really want to know. 

On the other hand The Sexy Brutale does deliver a solid gameplay experience.  People have called it "Groundhog's day in video game form."  And that works for the most part.  The entire game has the player reliving 12 hours, and trying to "save" people.  To do this, the player has to stop their death, which can be as simple as Activating a control panel, to as complex as timing a number of objects and following someone around.   It's a rather great game, that reminds me of classic point and click games. 

There's one big caveat on the game, the player is not allowed to stay in the same room as another person, so rather than being able to directly stop someone from an action, the player must set up rooms to avoid people getting murdered.  A rather interesting system if I do say. 

In addition the player has the ability to watch, listen and track people throughout the house, even listening in to private conversations.  It's actually rather fun to hear the NPCs talking and then trying to figure out how to assist these people avoid death.  I enjoyed the characters, and players quite a bit because they're all pretty unique, and they all have a great story. 

The gameplay itself is rather simplistic but works well, the player is allowed to explore the house at his leisure for 12 hours that takes close to 12 minutes or so.  He's able to look at objects, observe rooms and even spy on adjoining rooms to watch something happen.  All these tools help inform the player of what's happening.   The player can sometimes interact with objects and thus stop the murders. 

Really the only problem with this game is there's very few red herrings, if you find all the objects that can be modified, you'll find all the pieces you need to solve the puzzle.  There's only one object that's not used for the story and it's used for a side achievement, and it doesn't feel necessary. 

I also didn't have problems with any of the murders except one.   I had the pieces but i tried to make it more complicated than I thought it was, I over thought it and spend half an hour trying to do something far harder than I needed to do.   Once I realize what I missed, everything fell into place. 

On the other hand a lot of times you'll have to listen closely or be in the right place at the right time to make sure you hear a key piece of information.  Sometimes it's required to solve a puzzle as it'll unlock a special door, or location, sometimes you just need to know what has been done that you have to undo to solve it.  So there's a good gameplay loop of trying to figure out what's going on or what's causing someone's death, and then working to fix it. 

In fact out of the 7ish "sets of murders" there's only one that I was underwhelmed at which is the last one.   In fact I feel the entire game's ending is weak.  The game tries to be headsy and deep, and the fact is, I liked the game for the simple fun of the gameplay and world, not for the huge story it tries to deliver.   It's not annoying (you don't have to try to prevent every murder in one run which would have been brutal) but the story doesn't develop the overarching story until the final minutes, and by then I didn't care, I felt like I saved people (at least once) and what it tried to deliver was too late to really have the impact they wanted. 

But does it ruin the game?  Nah, of course not, The Sexy Brutale is a great game, it's unique, novel, and wonderful.  Great graphics, great gameplay, and really the only flaw other than the story is length.  I did everything in the game in 8 hours, and the game doesn't really allow more to be done.  The idea of a "perfect run" is impossible as the game stops you every time you save someone, so I couldn't even try to do anything more.  Once you finish the game, collect all the collectibles, and use that red herring I mentioned, you're done. 

And you've probably had a good time doing it too.  So the question should be asked, Do you want a game that leaves you wanting more, or do you want a game that wears out its welcome.  The first is always better, and I think the Sexy Brutale errs on that side.   I want more, I want to see another mansion and another cast.  I want a remix, I want more.   And honestly, that's all good. 

So I recommend this game if you want something new, and unique.  It'll do both of those things very well.  It's a fantastic experience.   It is shortish (8 hours) but at 20 bucks, that might acceptable.  It also does go on sale often, but overall, I think the developer deserves the extra cash for delivering an excellent unique experience and fascinating stories.

Absolutely FANTASTIC game. I can't say much about this game because I wouldn't want to ruin the surprises, so just take my word for this. You won't regret your purchase.

I've always wanted "Groundhog Day" the video game. This is it.

The guests in the mansion relive the same 12 hours wherein they perish in the same greusome ways every single day, and you must find a way to save them. Of course, you can only save them if you know what happens in the first place. That's where your trusty pocket watch comes into play. Your pocket watch allows you reset the day to the very beginning before anyone has been killed by the mansion staff, and maybe, just maybe, prevent the guests' early demise. 

Every single puzzle in this game is incredibly smart, and very intuitive. The game mechanics are all utilized to perfection, though I would have liked to see a little more guest-to-guest interactions, as very few of their stories intersect a great deal.

There were a few situations where I had to look at a walkthrough. These situations were generally because I had given up on a certain lead because I felt as though I had exhausted every possible approach to a given circumstance, but in reality there was some very small, easy to miss detail (and one instance of what I thought was just bad game design), but these are all just a fraction of what is otherwise a 10/10 game.

TL;DR: 
Great story. 
Tons of lore (That you don't even have to look at if you don't want!)
Extremely smart and clever puzzles
Is groundhog day the game.
I very rarely finish games. The fact that I saw this one through to completion (and want to go back and find all the collectables) should speak volumes for this game's quality.

39304624.review:
This game managed to pull me in very quickly. A decently intriguing intro mixed with nice graphical choices and great audio. A very strong start and a pretty strong middle too. I'd say my biggest disappointments were the ending and the lack of a real reason for the masks chasing you. The vast majority of the time I'd ignore them and go about my business. The only time they were even a nuisance-and that's what they were, a nuisance-was when I was trying to take a good look at a room I was exploring and they'd bumble in or I wanted to be in a room and they were in there and I couldn't go in cause of it.

As far as the ending goes, I was worried here and there that the ending was going to be what it was and I knew pretty early on, but like I said the game intro and middle were strong enough to keep that nagging sensation at bay. Until I had to deal with the ending and I was essentially like 'Yes, yes. I have seen this kind of ending before'. Technically there is more than one ending I guess, but they're both pretty cheap.

Anyway, I haven't really talked much about the gameplay. I'd compare this game to a kind of old school graphic adventure game in a way because you kinda have to combine objects, but at the same time a LOT of it is super obvious and you don't have that many items at any one time so it's not really a big hassle. I actually don't usually like this kinda game, but the measure of control I was given was satisfactory enough to bypass the usual annoyances. I really like games that give you direct control of your character rather than pointing and clicking to where they go.

The big feature to the game is that you keep replaying the same day and you are trying to stop people from dying. This would have a lot more impact if it wasn't for the ending being so predictable, but it's still enjoyable to watch em die in various ways and then try to find out how you're supposed to save them. WITH THAT SAID. I solved two murders (after the first) by bumbling around and exploring. I literally didn't even know I was saving the first pair of people until it gave me a cutscene. Heck I hadn't even seen either of them die at that point either. So in terms of difficulty this game is way down there. You know a game isn't hard when you solve a puzzle without even recognizing that you're being tested.

Usually that would be a huge turn off to me but man, the music for this game is great! I love music that goes along with things, like really good music videos and such or games with soundtracks that match what you're doing and this game does a fantastic job of it! Really the music is strong enough to carry the game and in some ways it does. If the music wasn't in the game, I wouldn't recommend it I promise you.

The UI elements are nice and clean, but I find scrolling through the 'collectibles' to be a little tedious. I also found reading a lot of the collectibles stuff to be kinda nice, but some of it is a little repetetive and repeats the same stuff others say but say it in a different way...so that's kind of a bummer.

Graphics are nice and I did find MOST of the character designs to be pretty fabulous. The face reveal for the main character was a little lame. I guess mostly due to the anticipation built up to see him finally remove his mask and get someone so...meh relative to the other characters in terms of personality, but it might also be because I swear I have seen someone from some disney movie who looks just like him. I almost feel like it might be a reference to them too cause he also dealt with bombs...weird that I think that and it's from a movie I never even seen either.

Load times between rooms are sometimes obnoxious. This isn't mentioning that sometimes you'll go into a room and just sit there in a mostly black room waiting for it to load. The controls are good, but not amazing. There was a number of times I found my character getting stuck on something I thought I could pass through or the perspective made me feel like something wasn't there. Still I wish more games could reach this level at the very least. It's a very good spot to get to with a game.

The story is pretty good up until the end. I came into the game not knowing what to expect, but then quickly got the impression the game was going to end the way it did. Then about 3/4's the way through the game I thought it was about to take an unexpected turn. Then it went right back to where I was expecting and I was disappointed again. If you are younger or more inexperienced with this type of thing then you will probably enjoy the ending. I've seen this stuff in media a lot though. The whole 'It's me! I was the turkey all along!' is a concept I don't really enjoy. Also I question some of the logic behind what the character was doing at the end. I've seen this motive before and for someone like that I have to wonder how they reach the conclusion that they do instead of another one that involves just not being an idiot. Like for real.


To summarize:

Difficulty: C - The puzzles are usually pretty creative, but they're far from difficult. Just a little too easy to be truly satisfying.
Graphics: 7/10 - Everything is stylized and looks pretty nice. There's a handful of graphical design choices that make me go 'whatever', but overall better than average.
Music: Top Tier - The way the music is setup is pretty fuckin good. Not god tier, but really high up there.
Controls: Solid - They work. They're a little chalky from time to time, but they work which is actually quite good when you consider how shitty some games can make controls nowadays.
Overall Story/Plot: A multi-layer box of cookies with the last two trays already eaten when you get to them - The story starts quite strong. A good start and a good middle. Great characters with pretty awesome personalities. An ending that is yawn worthy.

I'd say this game is a well made game with a smart gimmick attached, but with a few flaws.

Also, zero replay value. The reason should be obvious, but I will tell you in case you do not know. Spending the entire game replaying small sections of the entire game makes for very poor replayability.

I thought I might like the game. I have rarely been this wrong.

First of all : remember this game is sold for 20 euros. (I let you convert it to your country's money but, spoiler : it's overpriced)

I will come back on the popular tags used for this game : 
- Adventure : Not really. There is not much thrill or action in this game
- Puzzle : Not at all, there is only a bit of thinking to do to solve the murders.
- Mystery : Yes, it's mysterious
- Time Travel : Not really, you're replaying the same day over and over.
- Story Rich : Lol, nope

This game has great ideas. Really, I enjoy the gameplay, following the victims, the murderers, needing to stay hidden, unlocking "powers". But it's way to dense : you just the powers one or two times, and it's already the end of the game. I solved some murders by pure luck, not knowing it would solve the actual problem. It looks like a problem to me when you can solve a puzzle without wanting to, when the game is partially based on solving them.
I encountered some bugs (room being dark for few seconds when I enter them), and the controls with the joypad are sometimes clingy. It may be a problem with the hitboxes, but sometimes I had to try many times to just open a doors, not counting the facts that certains objects near doors activates while you just try to open the said door.


This game is full of good ideas but definitly too short and too easy to discover the full potential. If you want a short game (+- 5h to complete the game, 10h or so for 100%) with a nice (but not more) experience, go for it (on sale). If you're looking for stealth, puzzles or great story, don't buy it.

39090373.review:
Another puzzle game, apparently I love reminding myself how stupid I am sometimes. This one is actually quite easy though in terms of the puzzle solving to be fair. The immediate thing that made this game stand out when I saw a video was the way it looked. It's got a cartoon art style and the characters seem to be bobble headed thunderbirds in the way they move about. It's all set in a beautiful huge gothic style mansion that's great to explore, and doing so actually benefits you as it's full of secret passages. Pretty much every room in the game, even the short hallways, will have at least a couple of points of interest for you to look at. Occasionally this does something to help you with the puzzles but mostly they just have a couple of short lines of flavour text that do well to add to your immersion into the setting. The music is absolutely fantastic too, a different track for each area of the mansion and mostly lively and upbeat jazz tracks to juxtapose with the story. 

The premise of the game is that a masquerade party is being hosted at the mansion and throughout the evening the staff of the mansion are murdering all of the guests one by one so you need to save them. It's not really made obvious who you are but something strange is going on because your first interaction is with a woman who seems to be made of blood and appears through the floor to explain this to you. The masks that all of the guests and staff are wearing react to yours to prevent you from being in the same room as them so you need to go around the mansion looking through keyholes and listening out to the conversations of the guests to work out how to save them without ever actually being in the same room as them. At the end of each day in the game the clock rewinds and you start again with all of the knowledge you gained from the previous day, but none of the items. Each guest you save takes off their mask and you gain it's powers, usually giving you access to areas of the mansion you couldn't go before, along with other benefits.

The map in this game is superb and not something I've ever seen done before. Not only does it map out the entirety of the mansion that you've seen before, but if you've looked through a keyhole to watch one of the guests/staff in a room it will mark that on the map too. The map then has a clock that you can change the time on so you can scrub through a day looking at the map to trace the movements of people that you've watched previously to help you fill in the gaps.

As I said before, the puzzle solving in the game isn't exactly challenging, there's way more emphasis on just exploring and learning about the guests and their backstories through listening in to their conversations. Most of the puzzles will be pretty clear to you simply by spending a few days following the characters involved in this particular murder, and you have to do them in a set order, but it is the following them around that I enjoyed rather than the satisfaction of solving a puzzle. One nice touch is that even though you've saved a guest, you have rewound the clock to save the next, so as you investigate each murder you can clearly hear all of the people you've saved previously being murdered at the exact same time every day - [b]7.5/10[/b]

39037701.review:
Buying it due to the beautiful artstyle, I was thrown into a game with many problems, but has a very interesting setting.
The Sexy Brutale is a puzzle game that plays out very similarly to Groundhog Day, where one has to try to prevent deaths happening on only one day in-game. This mechanic is put in the game via a pocketwatch, multiple clocks and windup keys thrown throughout the game.

The game mainly uses one's mouse to move, and keyboard to interact with the environment. The character himself does not have a life bar, and only one way to die. Due to this, gameplay is more laid back and relaxed.

Puzzles in the game uses in game time, where every one in the game(excluding the player) has a set routine, a set way to die, and a set time to die. As a player, one needs to find a way to prevent these deaths. This is where the time mechanic comes to play. Some items are fixed in the game, others are found only after a certain time when an NPC puts the object there. This itself is interesting as some puzzles require one to be in a specific place at a certain time. There are no enemies in the game, however, one is able to die if stayed in a room with an NPC for too long.

The setting of the game is beautiful, and the art style compliments this. The character design, along with the environment design stays cohesive as one walks through the corridors and rooms of the game. Characters are design with a 'chibi' artstyle in mind, and are all kept unique on one way or another. The environments are detailed and it's easy to see all the work put in it as the game is played in an isometric -esque way.

The music in the game is just as good as it looks. The soundtrack mainly sounds akin to something from a jazzier era.
They're all very unique and is a treat to listen to as one plays through the game.

The story itself is a rather odd thing for me as it did leave me a sense of satisfaction, but did fall into cliches at times. It is rather short, and simple but as I've stated, it gave me a satisfied ending.

The game is not without problems. One of which is that the puzzles are mostly very simple and almost always well telegraphed. They are well designed, no doubt, but once one notices the telegraphs, the puzzles become a breeze. Puzzles are often contained in one area and are compartmentalized. Due to this, the mechanic isn't well used and should have been expanded more. However, I feel that it can be more enjoyable if played while just sitting back, and relaxing with someone as both of them can talk through the solution before actually settling onto one.

Another problem I find in the game is that there are numerous delays when loading into other areas. This occurs almost always when one tries to go through a door. This is a small problem, but it did get in the way when one has a feeling of urgency, and frustrating when being chased as it halts one completely into one spot.

A third problem in the game is the lack of graphics settings. The game itself runs well enough, but the lack of any adjustable graphics settings is a small bother.

Overall, it was great and I enjoyed it immensely. The game looks and sounds beautiful, puzzles are varied, and the story is engagable, despite its flaws. The problems I have stated are easily ignored, as none of them are really game-breaking.

39022463.review:
I'll be honest, I had a little bit of bias towards this one because I came to know of its existence from Jim Sterling's preview and I had an entirely different type of game in mind. Glad I was partially wrong.


SPOILER

This game is basically "Silent Hill 2 lite". The inspiration becomes clearer at the end.

END SPOILER


The titular Sexy Brutale is a huge mansion in which a plethora of characters from different social classes will gather to have fun and play cards, drink, chat, dance and die. Die horribly, in many ways.
The player controls Lafcadio Boone, a gentleman guest just like the others, who appears to have been stunned inside the mansion's inner chapel. From there, with the help of a mysterious, bloodied girl, Laffy will receive a very special power that will grant him the ability to rewind time using a pocket watch. As more sections of the mansion get explored, the player will be able to witness many murders and figure out a way to stop them one by one, rewinding the day over and over again with the ultimate goal of uncovering the mastermind behind this sick game of life and death.
The gameplay is very simple, it all controls and feels like a point-and-click adventure, with an inventory and a section for lore \ collectables. the Z key is used to combine an acquired item with an object in the world, the X key grants Laffy the ability to look into the next room while spying on the keyhole, and the Right Mouse button is used to interact with pretty much everything. Left Mouse button to run around.

About halfway through, you will see the pieces of the puzzle coming together if you are used to this type of stories, as it's not too hard to complete and the plot overall takes no more than 10 hours to be unfolded, second runs are optional and add some extra layer of usefulness to your repertoire, but that's only if you are into collecting cards or invitations to the mansion.


The Sexy Brutale is, in the end, "a tragedy played safe", with familiar tropes and recognizable inspirations, but nonetheless appreciable, easy on the eyes with its colorful and consistent artstyle, filled with references and very well directed when needed be. The only real problem I have with it, is that there's no option to rebind keys, but that's a minor complaint. The game works and works well.

8\10

I recommend playing this game with no idea of what it is. If you've already got the game, go play it with no idea what it's about, as the experience is better that way. If you're unsure if you want to buy it, it's a little more tough to go in entirely blind. I'll try to give enough info to make that decision, but little enough that it allows you to retain some sort of ignorance going into it. The gameplay isn't anything to write home about (a few aspects of gameplay are pretty unique), but it is a fun game with about 6-8 hours of diversion, and an interesting story. It is best played with a gamepad. It has no replay value, though.

Below, I'll be giving away information about the game that you learn within the first 30 minutes or so of gameplay. [Minor spoilers]

The Sexy Brutale is a mass-murder mystery that messes with time. The name of the game refers to the casino that goes by that name in the game. The game isn't at all sexy - it's just an unfortunate name.
You will search for clues to relatively simple puzzles that allow you to make progress in discovering the mystery behind all the strange murders. However, every midnight, time reverses and the day repeats itself, resetting any good you may have done. Only your knowledge, a few special unlocked powers, and a trio of items will continue with you - even the efforts you take to stop the murders will be reset. Who is responsible for all these orchestrated murders?

[h1] Longhand Review: [/h1]

I have no idea why but at first glance I thought The Sexy Brutale was a cludo-like multiplayer game. In truth I wasn’t paying much attention to the trailer, nor did I read the official Steam description or the popular tags the first time I was on the store page.

The Sexy Brutale is a very intriguing murder-mystery puzzle game, centred around a mechanic that allows you to bend time in order to save the guests of The Sexy Brutale Casino Mansion from being killed by the mysterious, superbly sarcastic staff. Instead of finding out who killed (or attempts to kill) the guests you witness their deaths first hand and attempt to save them by interacting with the environment and picking up key items. Although you’ll wonder why they’re killing off the guests and who is ordering them to…

This is an interesting concept with each of the 10 guests’ deaths being unique and eventful in their own way. When I had to solve each death I spent way too long on some. Most of the time I’d forget about interacting with certain items like a fish tank, instrumental in solving one of the murders. Some people will breeze through this game, others will take longer which isn’t necessarily a bad thing as the visuals and the music is easily the best part of The Sexy Brutale and have been crafted with a genuine love and care.

If you enjoy puzzle games there is a lot to love here, but whilst some love it I can appreciate this game not being for everyone. I previously said “Some people will breeze though this game”. It could feel rather short to some players which wouldn’t be a problem if it weren’t for the story. It’s odd addressing one of the best/worst things about the entire game. I’m still on the fence about out. I like aspects about it and it has a HUGE twist towards the end which I found intriguing but  I’ll let you decide if you like it (if you don’t buy/finish the game you could always watch a walkthrough, I’ll link one at the bottom just in case). However I can understand if the story leaves something desired for some. 

Thank the lord there is a secret ending which is achieved after finishing one of the worst card games ever invented, 52 pickup.

This game has a lot of charm, wit, humour and soul. From watching videos of the creators talking about it, it’s clear they hit the nail right on the head when it came to setting out what they wanted to achieve with this game. 

[h1] Would I recommend you buy this game? [/h1]

 I believe a majority of people would enjoy this game, a minority of people would appreciate the artistic elements of this game and I for one will remember this game as one of the best experiences I’ve ever had with a video game although not everyone’s palette is the same.

Also whoever composed the main theme, have my children.

Thank you for reading and I hope I could be of help.

I thought this game was a bit slow at times, a bit too easy at times, and a bit too aribtrary at times. Yet, without a doubt, a few things are certain in my mind: This is a beautiful game with beautiful artwork and an absolutely *beautiful* story. The last thing I thought I would be doing is crying in this game, however I did.

First, this game is inherently intriguing because of its concept: You're in this enormous mansion with devilish servants that kill off guests simultaneously. Everything's multi-threaded. You have the ability to rewind back to the beginning of the day. That's interesting and that is potential.

However, I do admit that it gets a bit drawn out and overwhelming at times. The mansion is, well, humongous. Finishing one portion of the mansion, feeling proud, then unlocking an entirely new and unknown area can be a bit daunting. I didn't often find myself excited to go exploring this new area. Perhaps it's the bleekness that I'm discovering someone dying, or perhaps it's the dauntingness of starting from scratch in a new area where you don't know the rooms, the layouts, and the players nor their movements. However, it's good casual fun with the servants often giving more than enough hints if you stalk them around and listen into their conversations. 

The real part that surprised me is the story. I ended the game with the revelation that I really, genuinely, cared about the characters and their past and their story. I loved each and every one of their unique personalities, and above all: I love the main character. The antagonist and protagonist colors this story into a heart-wrenching and truly inspirational message in the end. I truly didn't think I'd leave this game having learned life lessons, but I think I did from this game.

To summarize my opinion: The gameplay is engine revving up for this game: It's unique and quickly gets your attention, yet dries up fairly quickly. The story, however, is the smooth drift onwards. The ending? That's the reward and final destination. It's a beautiful, beautiful ending.

Es una pena porque podía ser un juegazo si llegan a confiar un poco más en la inteligencia de los jugadores. Aún así, pese a lo que considero sus defectos, lo recomiendo a cualquiera que busque un juego de puzzles original.

The Sexy Brutale parte de un concepto bastante original: estás encerrado en una mansión en la que se repite, una y otra vez, el mismo día en el que mueren todos los asistentes a una excéntrica fiesta de máscaras. Nosotros somos los únicos que podemos salvar a las víctimas y para ello debemos espiar los movimientos de unos y otros para frustrar los asesinatos.  El juego consiste por tanto en una parte de análisis (ir espiando los recorridos y sucesos) y otra de acción (encontrar objetos y usarlos en los lugares correspondientes). No es un juego difícil, ni siquiera exigente, porque no te pueden matar y el sistema de control e inventario no da para mucho. Se basa más en disfrutar de la experiencia que en desafiarte. 

Y con todos estos mimbres tenían para un juegazo. Pero se ha quedado en bueb juego a secas. Porque hay una decisión de diseño que no comprendo: no tienes libertad total para moverte por toda la mansión (que por cierto es bastante grande). En lugar de eso te van llevando de la mano de un asesinato a otro, de forma secuencial, desarrollándose estos en una zona relativamente pequeña. Y lo peor es que se notan demasiado 'las paredes' para no poder avanzar. Ver como tu personaje se detiene en medio de un pasillo y dice 'una fuerza espectral me impide avanzar' es un corte de rollo inmersivo total. Que sí, que luego explican el motivo de este impedimento pero, sinceramente, me parece prescindible.

Por la propia estructura de los asesinatos hay un orden lógico (porque cada asesinato desbloquea una máscara y con ella un poder) por lo que no eran necesarias estas barreras formales. Supongo que lo hicieron así para simplificar el juego, para que nadie se sintiera frustrado dando vueltas por la mansión sin saber que asesinato tocaba parar... pero es una pena. Porque repito: el juego es muy fácil, demasiado evidente. Precisamente esa pequeña capa de complejidad lo haría más divertido, probablemente más largo (en menos de tres horas lo ventilas) y no excesivamente complicado. 

Otro punto que me dejó poco satisfecho es que en ningún momento llegué a sentirme parte de la trama. Sí, eres un observador, y vas salvando gente que aparentemente te conoce. Pero no te sientes parte de nada. Quizás eso sea lo que pretendían los autores pero como jugador lo único que me impelía a salvar a esos tipos era ver que zona de la mansión se abría después. Y en un juego donde quieres que la historia sea parte central eso es un fallo gordo. Parece que como no sabían como hacer que el giro final fuera menos evidente (que lo es) quisieron enmascararlo todo (sin doble sentido) para que el jugador se sintiera perdido de forma muy artificial. 

Leyendo esto parece que no voy a recomendarlo pero ya habréis visto el pulgar hacia arriba. Sí que lo recomiendo. Porque pese a esos defectos reconozco que The Sexy Brutale es un juego muy arriesgado. Tequila Works no ha ido a la aventura fácil y ha planteado un formato bastante raro, complicado de describir incluso, y lo han dotado de un aspecto visual y sonoro precioso. Se nota buen el buen hacer en esta compañía española. 

Visualmente la mansión me ha recordado, salvando las épocas, a la famosa Abadía del Crimen, con una arquitectura espectacular (cada una para su época) en formato isométrico, muy detallada, con esos personajes que se mueven con las rutinas monacales.

A brilliant take to the adventure game genre, The Sexy Brutale is short but a delightfully bittersweet treat, an excellent mix of sight, sound, lore, and gameplay.  I'm gushing just a bit, true, but they should all be this good.

The gameplay is simple enough to summarize: from an isometric perspective, you wander a lavish mansion exploring details and finding the occasional thing to pick up and use.  The day repeats on a twelve hour loop (about 1 real life minute to 1 game hour), so you relive the same day, watching the inhabitants go about the same doomed routine that inevitably leads up to their murders, but you cannot be in the same room with them so you have to assist indirectly.  

Interrupt the murder, particulate in a cutscene of the grateful victims, and move on to the next area.  Get to the end, get to the bottom of The Sexy Brutale, find the true mastermind behind the murders, and put an end to it.  Or not.  After all, you have all the time in the world.  Shame the guests keep dying every time you reset the clock, even the ones you have saved, you even get audiably reminded as you wonder around the mansion who is dying from what.  Gallows humor abounds, but sometimes the humor takes a rest, leaving only the gallows.

Critically speaking, the biggest nit to pick is that the puzzles are overly simple.  Resist that urge to reach for a walkthrough, you shouldn't need it, the game will even spell out the answer to you if you're in the right place at the right time.  You might need help to collect all 52 playing cards and the guest invitations, a bit of a monotonous hunt, but that's quite optional, with a payoff no better than simply seeing the story to completion.  Even though the protagonist plods along at an old man's clip, the game is shorter than it first appears, and the sprawling mansion will feel small in the end.  I took my sweet time and I am at just under 11 hours with all achievements unlocked.

Yet, obviously the game holds together quite well, or I would not have been gushing over it.  The content is great, I really came to love the characters and the whole story, which was smartly planned, executed, and more than a little significant.  I do not reget playing it, I regret not playing it earlier.  I will be watching out for more from this developer.

38213235.review:
De la unión entre Cavalier Game Studios y Tequila Works, nace esta propuesta hispano-inglesa que supone sin duda un soplo de aire fresco a muchos niveles. The Sexy Brutale es un título que mezcla investigación, pusles o sigilo, para crear un gran rompecabezas con una clara premisa: estamos atrapados en un día que no para de repetirse en bucle, y estamos encerrados en una mansión donde los invitados a una fiesta tras sus puertas están siendo asesinados por el personal, y tenemos que evitarlo.

Así, con este planteamiento de "el día de la marmota meets Sherlock Holmes", tendremos que recorrer las distintas estancias de la mansión The Sexy Brutale, y salvando a todos los invitados que encontremos a nuestro paso. Pese a que la estructura de la mansión nos permitiría recorrerla de forma libre, el juego está planteado de forma deliberada para que hagamos un recorrido secuencial bien definido, donde cada nuevo intento de asesinato podriamos considerarlo "un capítulo" dentro de una intrincada trama en la que tendremos no solo que resolver estos asesinatos, sino quien y por qué está detrás de estos, y eso es algo que sorprenderá a los que lleguén al final de este título.

The Sexy Brutale es un juego que imita mecánicas de las aventuras gráficas, en su uso de la investigación de las distintas habitaciones, y la resolución de problemas planteados como puzles, o simplemente el abrirnos paso a través de la mansión usando objetos y habilidades. Precisamente las habilidades será uno de los puntos interesantes del juego, ya que a medida que rescatemos invitados, adquiriremos máscaras que nos harán ganar habilidades, y estas abrirán nuevas posibilidades jugables, desde ver espíritus de la mansión a escuchar conversaciones inaudibles, se suman ya a otras mecánicas iniciales como sería escuchar a través de paredes o mirar a través de los ojos de cerradura de las puertas. Estas mecánicas son vitales para poder resolver los crímenes y anticiparnos a estos en un nuevo bucle. Tendremos que leer patrones de movimiento, calcular el timing con otros personajes..., pero siempre sin que nos vean, ya que si coincidimos con otros personajes en una habitación, nos veremos en problemas, así que hay que andar con mucho sigilo.

El juego no es muy largo, y aunque ingenioso, tampoco es excesivamente difícil, lo que me ha llevado unas 6 horas en completarlo, y aunque tiene más de un final, puede saber a poco a algunos, pero aun así, el tiempo que dura no defrauda. El juego está en constante evolución durante el desarrollo añadiendo nuevas mecánicas, haciendo acesibles nuevos rincones de la mansión y permitiéndonos acceder a nuevos personajes que, como un reloj suizo, repiten día tras día la misma secuencia de actos con precisión milimétrica, en un intrincado y elaborado desarrollo sincronizado por parte de todos los personajes.

Gráficamente es agradable, colorido, las habitaciones tiene muchos estilos y los entornos se sienten detallados y con estilo, con unos personajes que se estiman de un estilo más caricaturesco aunque a decir verdad, el juego no deja mucho espacio para apreciarlos, pues la acción se siente siempre alejada de estos. A nivel sonoro tiene una gran banda sonora que combina estilos como el jazz, el blue o el swing, y los efectos tienen mucha importancia incluso en la jugabilidad, lo que le da más puntos a este. Lástima que el rendimiento no esté tan bien optimizado como esperaría de un juego que en ningún momento debería suponer un problema para equipos modernos, pero a veces tarda en cargar habitaciones o el protagonista no reacciona como es debido a nuestras acciones.

Al margen de todo ello, The Sexy Brutale es un gran juego que prima la exploración, la investigación y la resolución de enigmas tirando de ingenio y clase. Un tapado de este 2017 que cierra en breves, y que recomiendo a todo el que quiera una experiencia novedosa, original y que se mantiene interesante de principio a fin.

This one is tricky. Not that Sexy Brutale is not a good game, but it's also rather short and expensive for that and has some gameplay and technical issues. So, ultimately you have to decide if about 5 hours are worth 20 bucks to you.

What is TSB? It's a kind of murder solving puzzle game with a time rewind feature. Your task is to save the guests in the mansion, one by one. To do so you'll have to stalk their movements, listen to their monologues/dialogues and find out how/why they die and who the murderer is. These murderers are the household staff, which you can of course also stalk and eavesdrop on. With every piece of information you can in theory get closer to preventing their deaths, as every movement and every room you have explored is cartographed in a map that can be manipulated to show where a certain character will be at a certain time. Once you have enough information, or they have died or your 12 hour day is simply up, you can just restart the day from the beginning and try again. After you have successfully saved a gues you get a new special ability that will be necessary to save the next one. Make no mistake, the game is absolutely linear as far as I know. You can't just go everywhere, because paths will be blocked and guest can't be saved without certain abilities (like talking to ghosts).

Most of these cases aren't terribly difficult and are logical, however, there are a few point in the game where I was simply left clueless as to what I'd even have to do now to continue the game. With enough exploring you can get through usually, but a hint or two here or there wouldn't have been terrible, especially since interactable objects don't always make 100% sense. Who would think about filling an object with water to water a tree? Repeatedly? And some objects are hard to see and especially 1 little detail you've maybe noticed at the start of the game can suddenly be relevant again at the end of it. The way you can rewind time is very much like Zelda: Majora's Mask. You may follow one person, learn their movements and how they get killed, then rewind and follow someone else. You can listen to what the characters say at different moments of the day to get clues to prevent their death. Unlike a typical murder mystery, you don't need to reveal who the killer is, instead you need to prevent the death from happening.

The game is mostly linear, you prevent the murders in a specific order. When you prevent a murder you gain new powers that unlock a new area of the mansion. When you enter the new area, you have a vision of who you have to save next. You can revisit old areas to search for collectables you missed (or to just explore), but you never need to revisit an old area to prevent any of the deaths (i.e. you don't need to revisit the casino to prevent a death in the guest rooms).

You must sneak around and remain hidden from everyone, even the guests you are trying to save. You can look through keyholes to see a portion of whats happpening in the next room, or stop and listen for nearby footsteps and talking, You can also hide in a closet, this is similar to looking through a keyhole but you can see and hear the whole room and you don't have to worry if someone enters the room your in (no one ever checks the closets). If someone sees you, you just have to leave the room (your given plenty of time to do so), they don't keep chasing you once you leave. It's possible to quickly pass through areas with people in them (as opposed to waiting for them to leave the room) without any repercussions. I have no idea what happens if you just stay in a room with another character (not sure if your booted to the main menu or the day just restarts). The worst part, for me anyways, was the ending, I wont give away the ending, only that you don't need to peice together whats really going on, You are eventualy told everything without any test to see if you figured it out on your own (your just given few doors you need to unlock and then the antagonist begins walking you through everything), and I don't think it's possible to figure out the big secret on your own either. 37584069.review:
Welcome to The Sexy Brutale, an extravagant mansion and casino where in the midst of a grand masquerade party something far more sinister is afoot. This is one of my favourite puzzle games. You play as Lafcadio Boone who is trying to prevent the murders of The Sexy Brutale's guests at the hands of the staff, but there are a few catches. First of all, the day is on a loop. The day's events replay over and over again as everyone does the exact same thing without even realizing it. That is, until you come along of course. The second catch is that you can't directly interfere with the guests or the staff. Thus you have to find more subtle ways of saving the guests' lives. This results in a really fun puzzle game where you have to piece together the day's events while manipulating objects around the mansion in order to change them. You're a bit like a detective, except instead of solving a murder you're trying to stop one. And with each guest saved you gain a new power that adds another tool to your toolbox.
The Sexy Brutale is also gorgeous. The character designs are all very distinct with unique personalities. Plus if you like seeing some interesting and appropriately dramatic deaths, then this is the game for you. The music is also worth mentioning, because not only is it fantastic it fits the game perfectly. Each section of The Sexy Brutale has its own song, and because you're trapped in a loop the song syncs with the events of that area. What results is a heart-racing experience as you scramble to save the guest's life in time while the music ramps up in the background.
The only downside is that this is a short game. This isn't necessarily a bad thing as it means it doesn't overstay is welcome, but it is something to consider. In my opinion the length is mainly due to the difficulty of the puzzles. While difficulty is subjective, especially for a puzzle game, I didn't think they were very difficult. Overall I think I had more trouble with getting my timing down than I did trying to figure out what to do. My first playthrough took about 5 hours, and I did take my time to explore beyond the main objectives.
All that said, I had so much fun with this game. Every second I spent playing was well worth it, and I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a stylish puzzle game that won't have them rage quitting over the difficulty.

I found it a great little distraction from the more action- and fighting-oriented games. 
I guess the trial and error mechanics and short length also make it quite casual-friendly, so I would also deem it suitable for those that look for a more casual gaming experience.

Tl;dr: Not a big game, but a great bang for your buck.

The premise behind The Sexy Brutale is that your character is locked in a mansion during a masquerade party where all the guests are being murdered.  He's stuck in a time loop and has to keep repeating the day of the party until he manages to save all of the guests. It's an interesting premise, and the game does many things very well. It's a gorgeous looking game with a very fitting and expressive art style that really sets the tone for an extravagant aristocrat's casino/mansion. It's animated well and the sound compliments the setting perfectly. So why the negative review?

Frankly, the game is trivially easy. Although the mansion is nominally a large, open world to explore, in practice the game is divided into a number of discrete "levels" in the sense that you must save the guests one at a time in a particular order before the game will let you enter a new part of the mansion. Once you do move on to a new area you'll very rarely have any reason to return to an old one. Thus, you only ever have one puzzle at a time to solve, and the pieces you need to solve that puzzle will always be nearby. Compounding this problem is the fact that every interactable object in the game is painted with a bright fluorescent circle, so there's no possible way you can overlook an important item. It's literally possible (and happened to me) that you can accidentally prevent several murders just by aimlessly wandering around and clicking when you see a glowing circle, without even understanding what it is you're doing or why that particular circle stops the murder.

Perhaps my disappointment has more to do with my own expectations than anything the developers did wrong -- I was expecting something along the lines of the classic Maniac Mansion. Excellent game with a few significant (but manageable) flaws. The art style, the music, the setting, are incredible. It's loads of fun to run around stalking people through the casino day after day, watching the set-up to the murders, which are spectacularly horrifying if you actually take the time to just watch, knowing that something is about to happen. If you haven't solved the puzzle of how to save them, people WILL die, in a horrible fashion. It's quite a surreal experience.

Now, that leads me to the flaws. I strongly recommend that if you have a controller to hook up, USE IT. Not because this is an action game, but because the keyboard/mouse control setup is awkward (press SHIFT to spy through a door then press X to stop spying, wtf?!), can't be rebound, and can actively hinder your understanding of the game controls. For instance, you have control over time in this game. If you're at a clock, you can move time ahead to 4pm or 8pm. And while I had thought that you could also reset the time to 12pm, the start of the game's day, it frustrated me to no end because there was no option to do this at the clock where you can change the time to 4pm or 8pm. So I wasted an awful lot of time in the game because I would try something to stop a murder, it wouldn't work, I would know right away that it didn't work but there was still plenty of time left in the day afterward and I couldn't just tell the day to reset so I could try again right away. Turns out, the option to reset the day is an actual button you press, not an option in the in-game interactable clocks, and I never pressed that button while using keyboard and mouse because there was nothing but a visual button on the screen that didn't say anything about what it did, so I never pressed it. After a few sessions, I plugged in my controller to try that out instead and discovered this button within a few minutes because the button on the screen that had been labeled "F1" now said "LT" so my brain now needed to know what left trigger did, whereas it being F1 was just so generic that it never even registered as a thing that could do something.

Furthermore, the way you use your inventory items is really unintuitive. It took me a rather a long tiime to figure out how to set other clocks as spawn points because you need to use your pocketwatch on them to do that. The Achievement Hunters had even more problems figuring this out. It's not difficult, it's just not implemented well so it's easy to overlook. You have one active item, it's displayed on your screen- it'll be whatever you last picked up unless you switch to something else. You can rotate through your items on hand by pressing one of the two buttons displayed near the item on your screen. Using an item on something requires pressing a completely different button than interacting with the thing normally- you press X to interact with a clock but Y to use an item on it.

Also, there is at least one puzzle which can be solved via looking at information in the map, after you have acquired the item which gives you that information. You have to press SPACE in the map to open this information, and I never realized you could do this until watching Achievement Hunters play this game after I finished it. I picked up the item which gives you the information, but had no idea what it was and instead solved the puzzle via just running around for an excessive amount of time using trial-and-error of trying items in various places until finally something worked. 

And once you realize that sort of thing, this game possibly becomes too easy. I never had that problem while playing through it, I found most of the puzzles to be reasonably challenging to the point where I had to check guides to see how to advance at points, but if I had had a better grasp of the controls I don't think I would have needed to do that. If you watch the Achievement Hunters videos, they actually solve puzzles far too quickly without even fully realizing what they're trying to stop. And that's no way to play this game.

So, in a nutshell: use a controller rather than bad keyboard/mouse controls; F1/LT is your reset the day button; use inventory items with a different button than normal interact and scroll through them using the two buttons displayed next to the item; and just take your time and watch what's going on to best enjoy the game's atmosphere.

Visuals and sound design wise the game is absolutely stellar, but it’s squandered by extremely simple gameplay that doesn't really evolve meaningfully beyond the initial time repeat shtick, despite the advertised "bizarre mask powers".

Puzzles are too easy and most of the new mechanics you accrue throughout the game are unimaginative and lackluster, usually context based "press a button to activate door / gadget" type abilities rather than something letting you naturally manipulate the environment. The game even automatically chooses the mask ability you have to use for each situation when it becomes available, not that it would be hard to guess anyway.

For example the glass shattering and lock-picking powers are perfectly identical in how they’re used and only serve to open different types of “locks”. The architect insight power is left completely unused in puzzles and only serves to unlock more optional lore, again through contextual button press that you randomly get when walking through certain areas. Even the increased hearing ability that you can actually use everywhere and lets you keep track of people outside the rooms you occupy isn’t really used that way very much, only notably during segments where you peek through a keyhole and you guessed it, use a contextual button prompt yet again to make otherwise unheard dialogue visible. I’d wager it was originally intended to allow circumventing occupied rooms more easily (you lose if you’re in a room with someone else for too long), but the death timer is extremely lenient and you can just run through occupied areas every time, even straight through the masks that start chasing you. No need to hide in closets either, as they only grant higher visibility of the room compared to keyhole peeking.

The progression is linear and puzzles encompass only their own set new area the vast majority of the time, and even after the mansion slowly opens up there's really no cases where you have to run from wildly different areas of the map to gather clues or gadgets to prevent a murder. Pretty much each puzzle and its solution is isolated to the new area you just unlocked, save for one where you just have to manipulate 4 very obvious switches. The last power you get that lets you use an otherwise clever [spoiler]teleportation fast travel system[/spoiler] ends up being left completely unused despite perfectly lending itself for a grander mansion wide puzzle, and only helps speeding up a completely optional collectible hunt.

The story is merely decent, it’s not bad but nothing mindblowing either, and being a mystery game the lack of awesome moments where everything "just connects" and suddenly makes sense lefts a lackluster aftertaste.

The best way I can describe this game is by saying it's a reverse hitman. If you enter a room with people in it, time will stop and their masks will become sentient and chase you until you leave the room which is why you should avoid being seen. You could be anywhere in the mansion and you'd still know that things are getting urgent.

The puzzles rarely feel unfair. They are challenging but not too hard, often if you dont know what to do it helps to explore the mansion as new info can be revealed by spying on some of the characters. For example, in one chapter you have to name a password and you find out what the password is by spying on a character conversing with another one.

The only problem I had is that this game is technically poorly optimised. My PC meets this games standards and yet theres some dips in the framerate here and there. Theres also this annoying problem where when you want to enter a room the game has to process that for a second, which will result in you waiting in front of the door for a second and then entering it. It'll feel like you didn't press the button right. Often these hicc-ups are connected with the framedrops. These problems are inconveniences at worst though and never made me miss a prompt. Generally the timing in this game is quite forgiving.

Overall I'd say this game is a solid 9/10. I paid 10 bucks for it but I'd gladly pay 20 too.

Puzzle-wise, The Sexy Brutale is a little lacklustre. Perhaps only half of the few puzzles are good; the rest I blindly fumbled through. However, the story and environment make up for it (and this comment comes from someone who usually doesn't care about story and environment).

In The Sexy Brutale, you play as priest Lafcadio Boone, who runs around a giant mansion, witnessing the murders of guests at a party, and rewinding time to stop their deaths. The whole game takes place over the course of a single Saturday from 12 noon to 12 midnight, though time rewinds back to noon once you hit midnight.

The direct comparison would of course be to [i]Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective[/i], as both games revolve around the same premise. However, while [i]Ghost Trick[/i] has you stop the murder *while* it's happening, The Sexy Brutale has you stop the murder *before* it happens. It forces you to do this by disallowing you from being in the same room as another character, so you can never directly affect things in the room.

Another key difference is that this is a more isometric view, and you have free movement (as opposed to in Ghost Trick, where you can only move between cores). You also don't have any special ghost-powers. This makes for slightly-less-good puzzles in The Sexy Brutale, unfortunately.

The environment in The Sexy Brutale is superb, however. Since the whole mansion is a single setting, you can observe evidence of other victims' deaths while you're working on saving a different victim. For instance, one of the first victims you save dies from a gunshot at ~3:45. (His death, along with any other deaths you've prevented, resets when you reset the day.) No matter where you are in the mansion, assuming you haven't managed to save said victim, you'll hear that gunshot. You'll also hear a bell go off just before 7:00 (that's another victim), and some glass breaking at 4:15. This happens on every iteration of the day you're in. And indeed, the people in the mansion do react to these sounds, adding to the immersion.

Another way the game plays with the time-looping mechanic is with the soundtrack. The same ~6 minutes of soundtrack play throughout each iteration of the whole day. While the soundtrack changes with the room you're in, it's undeniable that it feels very much like you're playing through the day again and again, but trying to accomplish a different goal each time. Further, the soundtrack accompanies the murders well.

The controls, unfortunately, are a little weird for keyboard and mouse, and unfortunately aren't remappable. I don't know how good the game plays with a controller, but you may find it more comfortable using a controller instead. Regardless, this is a minor quibble I quickly got used to; the constant key-prompts helped, too.

Without spoiling too much of either game, I should also note that the story in The Sexy Brutale isn't as intricate as that of Ghost Trick, and nor are the puzzles; if I had to recommend only one of the two, it would be Ghost Trick hands-down. Nevertheless, both games told the stories they wanted to tell well, and The Sexy Brutale has a more immersive world than that of Ghost Trick.

Point is, The Sexy Brutale is a good game in its own right. It may not be great puzzle-wise, and it may not surpass Ghost Trick in terms of story intricacy, but its world is very well-made and is enough to carry it through from "just OK" to "pretty good". Get this first if you like a neat story with a good environment, and if you feel like the "stop the murder from happening" type of puzzle felt fresh, feel absolutely free to buy Ghost Trick as well (on Nintendo DS or iOS).

34889118.review:
I was one of those who really, really wanted to like this game.  Unfortunately, given what the game actually is, I can't recommend it.  

What I liked about The Sexy Brutale has already been covered in depth by others: the artwork and the atmosphere are quite beautiful (I especially liked the combination gasmask/playing card idea for the staff).  The characters have good backstories which keep them from becoming two-dimensional.  The brochure, which contains information and backstory for the hotel and updates as you play, is an excellent idea.  The dialogue is passable and appropriate for the characters.  A shadowy, chained figure waiting for his cards is something I find very intriguing.  

And there the list of positives ends.  I will list the negatives in order of importance.

The first negative aspect of the game is the name itself, "The Sexy Brutale."  While I don't necessarily agree that use of the word "sexy" will lead prospective gamers to expect sex, I still think it was a mistake.  You simply don't find casinos or hotels with the word "sexy" in the name.  In fact, you don't find any high-end establishments where the word "sexy" is featured.  It doesn't need to be.  "The Brutale" by itself is a superior name, and it's not even my first choice. 

Secondly, this has been referred to as a puzzle game, but the actual puzzles presented to the player are so simple that it's tempting to call them pseudo-puzzles.  All too often the object needed to solve the problem and save the guest is laying in the open for no apparent reason.  I assumed (incorrectly) that the puzzles would become more complex as the game progressed, and more than once found myself overthinking the problem; the solutions are uniformly unsatisfying because they are so simple, and sometimes that simplicity makes them seem downright unrealistic.  Guests can only be killed in a specific time and place, so that saving them can be as easy as keeping the staff away from the appointed place during the appointed time.  If you're expecting the target to be chased through the hallways by a determined killer, you will be disappointed.  Once the initial murder is foiled, the game considers the guest in question perfectly safe. Furthermore, foiling the murder usually comes down to using a single quest item one time.  There are no intricate problems to untangle.  

Lastly, the ending is absolutely abysmal.  "It was all a dream" kind of abysmal.  There was a period of time, maybe in the late 90's, when every other horror movie ended with the revelation that the main character had multiple personalities, and none of what you just watched actually happened.  The Sexy Brutale's storyline ends with a silent, wet fart.  The reveal is the definition of anticlimax, where the original sin of the antagonist and the premise of the entire game are shown to be incredibly mundane and well-traveled.  It also accidentally destroys the backstory (as revealed through dialogue) of the protagonist, Lafcadio Boone, without any explanation, so that the lack of originality is exacerbated by sloppiness.  

The Sexy Brutale could have been saved by better puzzles and a decent story.  As it stands, it isn't worth anything close to the asking price.

The most fun I've had playing a puzzle game in ages. Your job is to prevent the mansion staff from murdering the guests which involves discovering the victim/murderer's whereabouts and finding ways to put a spanner in the works. Save the guests and discover the secret of the mansion.

The time travel mechanic works brilliantly, peeling back another layer of the mystery with each cycle while a steady stream of new skills let you revisit old areas with new eyes. The soundtrack is also set to the 12 hour cycle and includes sound effects for key moments in each guest's story. Like many of the game's clues, these won't make much sense at first but the further you progress, the more you'll recognise cues from what's happening in other parts of the mansion, making connections that tie the multilayered story together.

Gameplay: The concept is really cool. Basically when you start the day, every NPC has a starting location in the mansion. They have a set routine that they do throughout the day. But at some point of the day they will be murder by the mansion staff. You have to one by one save people from their deaths by manipulating the enviorment. Sounds really awesome! 

But once you get into it, the puzzles you have to do save people aren't as complicated as one would hope. Often the most difficult part of the game is figuring out which character to follow at what time so they can say a keycode to a door or reveal a hidden passage for you to use. Some of the puzzles do require a few more steps than others but they usually involve with getting into a room and hitting a button. There were a couple of times where I found the solution, I was able to solve the puzzle on the first try, which for a game about starting the day over again, I shouldn't be able to do. 

Each puzzle takes place in the own part of the mansion, which is a big let down. These puzzle feel very isolated, and they have nothing to do with the other puzzles for the most part. I feel it would be a stronger game if the NPC patterns had a lot of cross over. Where I had to know the timings of the characters to get certain items or wait for them to change the enviroment in someway. But for each of the puzzle, you're just dealing with the victim and the mansion staff who are trying to murder them (which is usually one person). 

This game had some really good idea going for it. But it just falls short of a recommendation for me.

Overall, the Sexy Brutale is definitely worth playing. It can probably be completed in about 5 hours, and has a great style, with art, music and theme coming together very well. However, for experienced puzzle solvers, or point'n'click veterans, the solutions to each mystery will seem somewhat shallow for the majority of the game.

The Groundhog Day comparisons are almost universal, and with good reason. However, I think it is also worth comparing The Sexy Brutale to both the N64 classic 'Majora's Mask' (you are locked in a timeloop, and each time you go through it, you progress a little bit forward; not to mention the theme of masks both games have) as well as the most recent 'Hitman' (similarly playing through the same space of time over and over, where instead of trying to make creative murder happen, you instead try to make that creative murder... not happen).

The game does have a few strikes against it. Its time mechanics are a bit underdeveloped (better time manipulation and/or access to fastforwarding are the primary concerns). The game has a tendency towards slightly simplistic puzzles (a 'complex' mode a la Hitmans Professional mode would be much appreciated, even if it might jar with some of the themes). The game also makes each 'case' very isolated from the rest of the mansion and the other victims (which makes the mansion feel less like the sprawling party it is clearly supposed to be). Finally, the game unfortunately saves some of the best concepts and ideas for the end (the 'Arm' idea have a LOT of design space in my view).

These shortcomings, however, are not nearly enough to make The Sexy Brutale a bad game, it merely keeps it from being an instant classic. The asking price is perfectly reasonable, but if you can get it on a sale, be sure to grab it immediately. Score (if you are into such a concept): 4/5

Now don't get me wrong, 50%+ sale and it's not a bad buy. However, for the full price, they are asking? Never. This review is spoiler free, however, this first bit is all you should really read to have the best experience if you wish to buy it.

The puzzles:
The actual meat of it all! The tutorial puzzle is simple enough, and I understand leading people into it, even if they refuse to let go of your hand. The second puzzle was horrific, having little to nothing to do with the base mechanics of the game. It's too simple and could be completed the same "day". The third puzzle is much more tricky than the first two as it does require you to think just to get there. It doesn't leave you guessing on how to progress as long as you watch and check every nook and cranny. This was one of my favorites. The forth puzzle is easier than the last. It would have made a better second puzzle. It makes a good use of the mechanics of this game while not being hugely difficult. The fifth puzzle is a funny one. It isn't too difficult and is something that uses previous mechanics. Nothing special though. The sixth puzzle is a doozy. This one requires you to explore a lot to find everything. I would like to say this was a gem, but they added randomness into the required pieces. Had that not been the case this would have been my favorite. The final one was an interesting one. Just getting there is the first and most interesting puzzle. As for the real puzzle, you really have to think outside the box and it isn't terribly clear, but not impossible. An interesting and creative end, but nothing to write home about. 

Overall lackluster puzzles that don't make full use of the main mechanics. I wish they could have used the ideas from the forth and the 6th more, minus the rng. It could have been a great game.

The Story:
The story is interesting. I wouldn't buy it for the story but it does wrap everything up. It even explains the little details you see. Nothing overly flashy or fascinating though.

The collectibles:
The cards are scattered throughout the mansion and there is no clever trick to finding them other than clicking on every nook and cranny and being lucky enough to check a place early. Some are timed. There are only two collectibles I can think of that involve any ingenuity, and that is being generous. This adds nothing to the game and you are better off using a guide.

The alt-ending:
I wouldn't call it a real alt ending. For the effort it took to reach it, it was a massive middle finger.
