33978589.review:
Sexy Brutale might be my game of the year. It's a well put together mystery puzzle game, and since it's a mystery, It's hard to write a review without revealing too much. They do a good job keeping the answers tantilizingly out of reach, and the answers you do get lead to more questions. This helps make the core mechanic, the time traveling watch, from getting too tedious as you repeat the same day over and over. Each new attempt gives you an opportunity to explore and discover, to put the pieces together of the mystery and the solution to the problems you are presented. 

The whole game is saturated with character, making every area interesting to navigate and explore. The writing is phenominal for the most part, with each character being unique and feeling like a person you interact with rather than an object for you to play with. Each person also has their own paths that they take over time, making your navigation, and their movements, into intricate choreography. 

The sound and music is also mosty fantastic. The music doesn't just sound good, but the music in each area is lined up with the time and nearby events. During the game, you can also hear different sounds coming from distant areas at the same times, creating a mystery as to the identity of the source, and making you feel clever as you discover them and identify them as they go off when you try again. These two factors together make the whole game feel cohesive and helps you know not just where you are, but [i] when [/i] you are, as the tention builds and you run out of time. 

The sound isn't perfect though. In particular, after a certain mechanic is introduced, entering or peeking into certain rooms plays an obnoxious sound that's louder than anything else. Also, there is no transition between the music of the different zones; it just cuts from one song to the other. This is mostly fine, but moving from some areas or during different parts of the music can create a jarring shift.

Two last complaints: The major complaint is optimization. I don't know if it's my computer, but it shouldn't be, since it runs more complicated and graphics intensive games just fine. The game runs smoothly during most of it, but it stutters as it loads new rooms. From what I can tell, it loads a room as you enter it, and keeps it loaded until you hit certain areas that unload the previous area, so it's not too bad. The minor complaint is the collectibles. I probably got about 98% completion on my own, and for the most part everything is straightforward. I did look up a walkthrough for the rest, and I would say about 1/2 of the missing collectibles I missed due to a lapse in my judgement. There's 3 or 4 that feel like it would take random chance to find on your own, and I hate using walkthroughs, so I was mildly annoyed.

This game is a real masterpiece though, despite the minor nitpicks here and there, it thouroughly captivated me. I got completley immersed, and hated anytime I got interrupted playing it. You should pick it up, and when you do, set aside a couple 4-5 hour blocks to be able to play as much as you can while stopping as little as possible.

It was on sale this weekend, and I've thought it sounded interesting for a while now. I started playing it the day that I bought it. And I kept going, and going, and going. I was irritated when I had to stop and make some food for dinner. I paused the game, put something in the micro, sat down and played a few more minutes, and forgot about my food. An hour later, I remembered, hastily ate my cold burrito able to spare 5 minutes away from the game, and then went back to work solving the mysteries of this bizarre mansion/casino with it's colorful cast of characters and carefully crafted plot.

Then I beat the game. Then I kept going until I had found all of the achievements. I was fully satisfied.

If you haven't read other reviews or heard much about the game, it works like this: you are in a mansion full of npcs who are moving about and participating in various simultaneous stories according to a script. Some of the npcs are setting up devious murders.

You are able to sneak around, but are generally discouraged from being in the same room as anyone, so you will have to spy on them from the next room, or hide in a cabinet. Ostensibly, your task is to find ways to interact with the environment in such a way that the murders are prevented from occuring. This involves memorizing who is going to be where, when, what they interact with to execute their plans, and then being sure to muddle things up at the right moment. But really, there are deeper mysterious to uncover, and it is more about understanding what all of those simultaneous plots are telling you about the bigger plot.

I just want to add that the aspect of time is very nicely tuned. You never feel like oppressed by it, and it doesn't move too slowly either. Because of the clocks - which let you change where you start the day - if you are ever out of time you can just reset and carry on with whatever you were attempting to do. It's more about understanding the space of time and how events are mapped to it, rather than it being something that limits what you are able to do.

Ultimately it's the kind of concept I've always wanted to see done well, but aside from a few attempts here and there, and the dark shadow of the moon in Majora's Mask, the groundhog day formula is one of few formulas in gaming that hasn't really had enough experimentations to produce the definitive example, the way things like Dark Souls or Diablo have for action rpgs; wow for mmorpg; ocarina of time for action adventure; forza or gt for racing/car porn, etc.

The Sexy Brutale is what I will point to from now on. "Oh, you mean like the Sexy Brutale?"

+ unique gameplay
+ distinctive and beautiful art
+ great script/plot (for the most part)
+ engaging story you really come to understand due to repeated viewings and interactions
+ ability to move starting spot keeps each "run" from feeling overly repetative
+ MUSIC!

- gameplay tone changes somewhere past the middle and I was less engaged
- ending was not the worst but I'm not sure it quite stuck the landing
- some mechanics underused (super-hearing for instance)
- You can only skip time forward to 4pm or 8pm. A few more options there would have been nice.

This is a fun little game, with one significant flaw - the controls.  Initial setup for this game is an absolute pain due to horrible control implementation.  For some reason, the game cannot differentiate between the different controllers you may have plugged in or active - including virtual controllers.  It will process any input it thinks it is receiving, and you cannot set a specific controller.  In my case, this prevented me even from using the menus - I had to force-close the game from Windows because I could not control anything in-game.  To resolve this issue, you need to have ONLY the controller you will be using active.  You must unplug all other HOTAS, joysticks, pedals, controllers, and I even unplugged my Vive for good measure.  You must also disable all virtual controllers.  I see this as a cardinal sin in game development - there is no excuse for having to mess with other hardware to make a game work  That knocks the game down from an easy 4.5 stars to maybe 3.

Once you sort out the controller fiasco though, it really is a charming little game.  Puzzles often tend to be a bit easier than my over-thinking brain comes up with, artwork and overall design is very good.  I'm sitting at 5.5 hours as of the time of this writing, and am probably around 3/4 of the way through the game, and judging from other reviews, it looks to take anywhere from 6-12 hours to finish, depending on how much of a completionist you are, and how quickly you figure out the puzzles.

The mechanics are fairly forgiving - if you make a mistake, you can "rewind" the day to noon any time you want, or if you run out of time, you automatically rewind at midnight.  Advancement is handled nicely - even if the person you're currently trying to save dies, you can still explore to find more information, items, or environment objects to use next time through that day.  Spy on people to see where they are and what they do at what time, and as you progress, your map records where these people were at what time.  You can scrub the time forward and back on your map to help you plan your own movements, etc. - pretty key in one particular part, but useful other times too.  When time rewinds, you lose any objects you collected, but you do not lose information - key codes, movement of victims/staff, locations of secret doors/panels, etc. stay with you through any further rewinds.

If you can get past the absolutely irritating issues surrounding getting the controller working (and remember, you have to unplug/disable all other controllers BEFORE you start the game), it's worth your time.  I personally would say the game is worth $10 rather than $20 due to how short it is, but if it weren't for the controller problem, I wouldn't feel bad about spending $20 on it due to how polished the rest of it is.

[h1]苦涩的后悔药
——评《The Sexy Brutale》[/h1]

[i]如果有一天，你得到了后悔药，你会吃掉它么？[/i]

邪恶的面具控制了庄园的侍者，将庄园主人的朋友们逐个虐杀，一位带着面具的男子借助怀表的力量，在迷人庄园里重复着悲剧上演的那一天，避开被面具的侍者，拯救被谋杀的宾客，在鲜血女子的引领下发掘迷人庄园的真相，这就是《The Sexy Brutale》中所讲的故事。

作为一部解密游戏，游戏的谜题设计相当精巧，难度适中。玩家需要先探索庄园的各个房间，窥视宾客的死因，摸清谋杀者的行动规律，像摆多米诺骨牌一样，利用面具的力量改变细节、引导游戏中人物的行动，避免悲剧的发生，获得被拯救者的面具力量，马不停蹄地跑去拯救下一个人。
和现实中的多米诺不同的是，玩家们的行动是“盲摆”，在最初，你不知道你的行动会导致什么结果，要经过一次次地尝试、回溯时间，才能慢慢摸索出正确的方法，在不影响平衡的前提下，抽走代表“死亡”的那张骨牌，进而改变一切。

游戏的另一个特色是“自由”，在迷人庄园中，只要你能避开面具的监视，并掌握某些面具的力量，便可以在庄园中来去自如，你可以冷酷地一遍遍观赏朋友们华丽的死亡，也可以去随意打乱角色的行动，零点一到，万象归元，一切取决于你的想法。

玩家操纵着三头身人偶行走在老式庄园箱庭之中，华丽的爵式风古典乐流转，音画表现力十足。面具的华丽、钟表的滴答声、谋杀的回响、奢华的厅室交织，仿佛恶魔在耳边低语：你，是一切的掌控者；你，是迷人庄园的主人；你，能改变那些惨剧...

当然，《The Sexy Brutale》也存在一定不足。游戏中有时会出现穿模以及操作失效的Bug，影响游戏的正常进行。另外，有些强运的玩家可能无需反复试探解谜，误打误撞就拯救成功，虽然这是游戏开放性的一种体现，但也凸显了开发组谜题设置方面存在的问题，希望在未来的更新中他们能对这些问题加以改善。

以下内容包含大量剧透，不喜勿看。
[spoiler]

在时间回溯与悬疑解谜的背后，《The Sexy Brutale》隐藏着一个自我救赎的故事。

为了怀孕的妻子，好赌的庄园主人铤而走险，试图纵火骗保，最后一搏。像往常一样，他没有获得胜利的筹码，而是输掉了一切。
主角的老友们因为各种各样的理由聚集在迷人庄园中，想在这灯红酒绿中将过去的自己埋葬，却因为主角的一时失误，在无尽的火焰之中葬送了的自己的未来。
主角侥幸身存，妻儿皆亡，旧友不存，偌大庄园空留碳灰，因纵火而锒铛入狱。

他悔。
悔恨到了极致，便有了后悔药。
还是那个庄园，还是那些朋友，还是那位娇妻，这次，一切都不一样了，没人会死于大火，时间会停留在这最终的、最美好的一天。

但这后悔药并非良药，暗藏剧毒：
醉心技艺的大匠，死于焦躁；
饮酒取乐的壮汉，死于鸩酒；
长目飞耳的妇人，死于好奇；
献身神秘的灵媒，死于孤独；
声遏流云的歌手，死于嫉妒；
偷天换日的窃贼，死于傲慢；
彬彬有礼的绅士，死于忠诚；
体弱智强的天才，死于信任；
力大无穷的忠仆，死于懒惰；
最后，
走投无路的主人，心死身存。

后悔药的药效已然消失，庄园主人再次发现了事实，
年轻的他清醒而冷酷，中年的他空虚而忙碌，年老的他悔恨而无助，
而现在，他还能身往何处？
是再吃下后悔药，还是在孤寂中老朽地死去？

吃了，你便能沉溺在美好的过去之中，去肆意改变，去惩恶扬善，去掌控一切...
不吃，你只能面对这冰冷的现实之壁，仍无能为力，仍孓然一身，仍举目无前...

[h1] What is this game? [/h1]
The Sexy Brutale combines the concept of [i]Clue[/i] (the board game) with time travel elements to provide a unique murder mystery experience. For the six of you that played [i]Ghost Trick[/i], you'll feel right at home here.

You play as a party guest in a mansion where the staff are brutally murdering everyone. Your goal is to save all of the guests [b]in real-time[/b] with the help of a pocket watch that lets you manipulate time. The core gameplay loop consists of exploring the mansion, gathering information on each character's actions and whereabouts via spying, resetting the day and then interfering at the right moment to prevent their gruesome fates.

[h1] You Should [b]Buy[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]The idea of real-time murder prevention is appealing to you
[*]You're looking for a good, concise story
[*]You want a slower-paced, easy/relaxing experience[/list]

[h1] You Should [b]Skip[/b] This Game If: [/h1]
[list][*]You want a fast-paced, action-oriented experience
[*]You don't like doing the same thing over and over (a problem with most time-travel themes)
[*]You want a longer gameplay experience (Brutale is roughly 6 hours, longer if collecting everything)[/list]

[h1] My Personal Opinion (Recommendation Reflects This) [/h1]
The Sexy Brutale sold me on its concept alone. Combine that with a great art style, cool theme and surprising good story, I can definitely recommend it to those looking for a unique time travel murder mystery. But it's not perfect. For one, the pacing seemed slower than necessary, mostly because your character moves at a snail's pace, and the time travel mechanics will often have you waiting for things to happen before you can progress. Additionally, I experienced weird extended loading times and graphical glitches whenever I entered rooms for the first time. However, these qualms shouldn't dissuade people from experiencing this wonderful game.

33576896.review:
In short, an amazing puzzle game with an interesting premise, excellent aesthetics, and a well told story.

As priest Lafcadio Boone, you must rescue guests from being murdered by the staff of The Sexy Brutale without ever being allowed to be visible to either the guests or the staff.  The mechanic stopping you does it in a nice way that prevents punishing the player from accidentally being in the wrong spot but also stops you from interacting in the rooms when you are.  Through a groundhog's day-esque mechanic, you repeat the day infinitely until you find the way to solve each particular murder, so it's best to just watch what unfolds once or twice before trying to do too much.

It's not a long game, although there are collectibles that unlock some additional content for those that are interested in being completionist.  Instead, The Sexy Brutale focuses on making the most of the time it does have you, and succeeds at it.  The amount of character and lore oozing from the game shows just how much the developer cared about making it.

That said, I think it should be said that this game is not going to satisfy hard-core puzzlers who like fiendishly difficult or complicated games.  The puzzles are interesting, but intuitive.  The true reward of this game isn't solving the puzzle, it's about exploring the mansion and observing all the particulars of each murder.  There's layers upon layers of stuff to find, and as you get further in the story you can appreciate more of it.  In a sense, getting the full picture of what's going on in each scenario is more of the puzzle than solving the murder.

TL;DR: rated 9/10 dead guests. Buy now if keen, wait for sale otherwise.

Lovely art style & cute character designs offset the brutal tragedy sealed up in the walls of the eponymous mansion/casino. Yes, the game is named after the location where it is set. If this bunches your panties for whatever reason, I'd suggest you have a look at some of Steam's other fine games. Life is too short to get infuriated over such developer choices or suggest lists of banal alternatives.

Gameplay involves sneaking around the sprawling mansion spying on everyone, picking up everything that isn't nailed down and figuring out to use it. Much of the challenge comes from figuring out where you need to be and when, then how to be there at the right time to do your thing, sometimes involving a chain of such planned actions. Feels different and fresh enough to be diverting. The day resets at midnight, giving you as many shots as you need at getting your current task right. Keeping everyone's movements and actions straight isn't too taxing as the game has a built-in system for showing character's movements on the map once you have observed them pass. You can scrub back and forth through the day to see where they're going and when so you can plan your own actions. So I'm going to assume you've read some of the other reviews. If not, after reading this go to most helpful and check them out. I'm not going to rewrite what others have said.

What is the kind of person who will enjoy this game? It is a person who is looking for a casual, relaxing, yet interesting game that doesn't drag on for days. It seems to take about 8 hours to finish and 10 hours to complete. I will not say that this game has a very in depth story. In fact it's rather simple, though with an interesting twist at the end, but it is interesting and I kept wanting to find out what the hell was going on. The puzzles are not too complecated, in my opinion, and at least one I found was quite poorly designed [spoiler]as it requires you to do a task then restart the day a few times[/spoiler], but the good thing is you don't need to be terribly precise with your timings, and even I didn't manage to "die" in my play through.

Now, for some of the bad things about this game. None of these are terribly bad or deal breaking, but they are still worth noting so you know what you're getting into. 

[list]
[*] [b]The majority of the dialog boxes are timed.[/b] I put this in bold because, as a slow reader, this was an irritation of mine. I would be half way through reading someone's dialog when it'd go away. [b]However[/b], none of the real important dialog boxes are timed, and require you to click in order to progress them. This is also true of dialog boxes that come up when you interact with something. This gives you time to read and understand it, however time is still ticking, so don't take too long.
[*] You can't rebind any of the buttons. This is unfortunate, as buttons they chose are rather odd (Z, X, 1, and 3). I also imagine that it might be an issue with those who have different keyboard layouts, but due to the slow nature of the game, it shouldn't really be a problem.
[*] There are no graphical settings, which is unfortunate. This game isn't really graphically intensive, so you don't have to worry about turning down graphics if you have an older PC, but it sure would be nice to be able to turn them up to make the game look even better.
[*] Between completing one murder and starting another, you really have no direction on where to go. You have to sort of guess some times. But I guess that's part of the nature of puzzle games where you have to retrack your steps. You have to remember you saw something earlier that you couldn't interact with because you didn't have the right item or ability.
[*] Occasionally, animations would get out of sync, but usually things got fixed on their own, so again not a big deal.
[/list]

All that being said, I whole hartedly recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzle games and enjoys a good aesthetic and a funky sound track. If you're looking for a challenge, you might be better off spending your money elsewhere. But if you just want a more casual experience where you can enjoy the game without being under pressure, this is worth the full retail price and worth your time.

33332441.review:
Short version: this is a fantastic premise and art design in need of better writing and scenario design. More of a proof of concept than a satisfying game.

Long version: 

I was real disappointed with this. Lost interest 90 minutes into the game and have shelved it for the moment. 

They have the great framework for a great game, and they certainly have the artistic talent. The problem is they just don't have the writing or design talent to go with it. 

The plot: Comparisons have been made to Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective. The plot in that game managed to make the player give a shit about the story right from the very beginning. Sexy Brutale...I guess they wanted to go for "mysterious" but they don't have the writing chops to pull it off, and you're given absolutely nothing to care about from the start. You're dumped into playing a mute protagonist with no background, trying to save people you know nothing about from murderers you know nothing about in a setting you know nothing about, and it's all presented not in a sinister tone but a whimsical tone like "Clue" so you're not even motivated by basic righting of wrongs. For all you know, the guests are evil and the servants are heroic resistance fighters. Even the people who have beaten the game say there's no plot to care about, until the very end where you get hit with a clumsy exposition dump.

The puzzles: Are far too simple. There are usually only one or two VERY basic and obvious steps to stopping each murder. The challenge isn't figuring them out, it's sitting through the tedious NPC travel routines waiting for the right time to do something. You quickly figure out the simple solution to stopping a murder, then spend five times as long peeking through doors waiting for NPCs to slowly waddle along and leave the room so you can do something. Worse is that, although you can rewind time, you cannot fast forward it and every rewind point is at least one full minute of real time waiting for key events. Every retried attempt is at least 60 seconds of just sitting there waiting for NPCs to run through the same routine. It gets old very very fast. The puzzles are 20% (very basic) deduction and 80% tedious waiting. This game would be great if they could get the Danganronpa writers who know how to write an intricate murder to solve.

That's not even mentioning the awful PC controls. Hold down right click to move (not right click to move, HOLD DOWN. If you let go you stop moving), left click to open door, then E and space to examine or peek through doors. It might sound simple, but trust me it's super awkward trying to play. It feels like a lazy DS port except it was never designed for touchscreen! There is no reason everything couldn't have been tied to left and right mouse clicks. It's definitely not worth $20. Even at 40% off for the summer sale I feel I didn't get my money's worth for 90 minutes until I lost interest. The only reason I can think of for buying this is supporting the developer enough so that they eventually get decent writing & design talent and release a proper game for this concept in the future.﻿

(for anyone thinking I can't review this after only 90 minutes, just how long should you give a game to give a good impression if the whole thing is only 4-6 hours long?)

Итак, "Секси Бруталь" - это название грандиозного поместья-казино, в котором происходят события игры. Владелец поместья, экстравагантный Маркиз, устраивает ежегодный бал-маскарад, на который приглашаются гости из его самого приближенного круга. Однако, в этот раз, вместо восхитительно вечера в кругу друзей, полного красок и роскоши, гостей Маркиза методично и, при этом, весьма изощренно одного за другим убивает персонал казино. Перед нами своеобразная детективная история, поскольку в этот раз нам нужно узнать не кто убийца, а какова причина совершаемых убийств. Наш главный герой - пожилой священник Лафкадио Бун, один из друзей и гостей Маркиза. Он обнаружил себя в очень странном положении: вместо того, чтобы быть убитым, как все остальные, он, из-за стороннего вмешательства, выпал из общего сценария событий, образно говоря. Всякий раз, когда временная петля начинается заново, он сохраняет свои воспоминания о произошедшем ранее. Его не убили, поскольку никто не может с ним контактировать. Проблема в том, что и он не может ни с кем контактировать - ни с жертвами, ни с убийцами. Всякий раз, стоит ему оказаться с кем-то в одном помещении, время останавливается и маски присутствующих, оживая, гонят его прочь. В результате, ему приходится наблюдать за разворачивающимися событиями со стороны - прятаться, следить, подслушивать, тем самым накапливая знания о событиях повторяющегося вновь и вновь дня. А уж эти знания должны помочь придумать способ, как предотвратить убийства, не взаимодействуя с жертвой и убийцей напрямую. Во всем этом Буну помогут появившиеся у него таинственные часы, позволяющие ему частично контролировать ход времени внутри петли - перематывая время вперед или начиная день заново столько раз, сколько понадобится.

Поскольку игра во многом держится на сюжетных поворотах и интриге, разумеется в ней должно быть что-то, что поддерживало бы определенную линейность прохождения. И здесь это реализовано с помощью механики, напоминающей принципы метройдвании: нам доступно для исследования огромное поместье, состоящее из разнообразных (и зачастую, невероятно красивых... или довольно жутких) зон, однако передвижения героя ограничены теми или иными препятствиями. Часть препятствий устраняется, с помощью полученных знаний - можно подглядеть, как кто-то пользуется потайной дверью, или найти записанный код от замка. Однако многие пути открываются, после получения героем тех или иных дополнительных способностей. Суть в том, что просто предотвратить каждое убийство не получится: стоит событиям дня пойти не как обычно, время перематывается назад, день начинается вновь и все вмешательства нашего главгероя стираются, как будто их и не было. Однако кое-что от спасенных гостей мы все же успеваем получить - будучи спасенным каждый из них снимет свою маску, что даст возможность с ними поговорить, чуть глубже проникнуть в суть происходящего, а также, в плане геймплея, получить новую способность. Эти способности позволят устранять препятствия и проникнуть в ранее недоступные зоны поместья, таким образом продвигая нас дальше по сюжету.

Собственно, такова основа геймплея: исследовать поместье, не попадаясь никому на глаза, следить за всеми, при необходимости манипулировать течением времени, использовать знания о том, что, когда и где происходит, чтобы предотвратить очередное убийство, получать от спасенных новые способности, которые позволят исследовать еще больше тайн поместья. Это одна большая головоломка, которую, на мой взгляд, очень интересно решать. Как и полагается в хорошей истории подобного рода, чем больше мы узнаем, тем больше смысла появляется в событиях, виденных нами ранее - разрозненные куски начинают складываться в целую картину, но разобрать таковую мы сможем, по-идее, только собрав все детали воедино. Будут, разумеется, и множественные детали, попадающиеся нам на глаза достаточно рано, но о смысле которых догадаться можно лишь много позже. И, конечно, я уверен, найдутся те, кто обо всем догадается заранее и к концовке подойдет с ощущением "я так и думал!". Хотя, не берусь судить, много ли таких будет в данном случае.

Убийства, которые нам предстоит срывать, как я уже упоминал, порой отличаются немалой изощренностью. Персонал действует весьма слаженно, реализуя схемы "казней", индивидуально подобранных для каждого из гостей. Иногда смерти подчеркивают те или иные пороки жертвы, вроде чрезмерной любви к алкоголю, жадности или нежелания подчиняться каким-либо правилам. При этом, многие убийцы демонстрируют изрядную долю черного юмора, максимально подчеркивая иронию каждой смерти, гордясь качеством своей работы и в целом ведя себя предельно спокойно и расслабленно. В то же время, смерти несут в себе немалую долю трагичности, поскольку жертвы в целом, не смотря на используемые убийцами пороки, вызывают сопереживание - наблюдая за ними, можно понять, что каждый из гостей не безупречен, но каждый, в то же время, имеет и располагающую к себе сторону. Способность видеть в каждом в том числе и хорошее - это, кстати, одна из тем, которые будут периодически подниматься в данной истории. Вообще, стоит повториться: никогда не знаешь, какой из мелких кусочков попадающейся здесь информации окажется в итоге намеком на грядущие события.

Вообще, контрасты настроений прослеживаются здесь регулярно. Собственно, сама концепция "Секси Бруталь" это воплощает - роскошное, красочное поместье, бурлящее жизнью и весельем, но наполненное темными тайнами и памятью о чем-то бесконечно трагичном.
 
А еще есть музыка... Которая попросту замечательна, но также отчасти связана с геймплеем, как и многие звуки. Все события дня в поместье происходят всегда в одно и то же время - именно это позволяет игроку, перезапустив день заново, знать его события наперед. И если мы слышим некий звук - значит, случилось какое-то ключевое событие, которое будет важно в дальнейшем. Иногда смысл того, что мы (и остальные посетители казино) услышим станет понятен не сразу, а иногда он будет достаточно очевиден ("- Вы слышали?! Что это было? - Нет, сэр. Я совершенно точно только что не слышал никакого выстрела, сэр"). Что же касается музыки, то каждая зона поместья имеет свое убийство - и свой саундтрек, подогнанный по ритму под разворачивающиеся в зоне события. Можете быть уверены, что перед убийством музыка станет потихоньку сменяться на более зловещую, достигнет пика напряжения в момент расправы, и вновь вернется к обыденному ритму после гибели гостя.

Я получил огромное удовольствие от прохождения этой игры. Сочетание нескольких достаточно редких концепций, - таких как непрямое вмешательство в события и сбор информации о происходящем внутри временной петли, - уже само-по-себе занимательно, а когда исполнено на столь хорошем уровне, воспринимается просто замечательно. Восхитительный способ рассказать восхитительную историю, как я считаю.

The Sexy Brutale drew me in more than I would have anticipated. I thought going in it would be a good little puzzler with a nice theme and interesting concept. 

The world that is created in The Sexy Brutale is fascinating. I found myself looking for every item (invitations and cards), and unlocking all the backstory just simply to read it. If you want to come into this game looking for a puzzler, you might find it a tad easy and short for the price. However, if you are willing to sit down, take in the sound,  the music, the backstory and simply enjoy a wonderfully charming title, then the world of The Sexy Brutale is one to savour.

33019605.review:
[h1]An intricately crafted time-loop murder mystery[/h1]

In The Sexy Brutale, you are a guest to a masked ball in a huge, ostentatious mansion - and like everyone else in that mansion, you are stuck in a time loop that resets ever 12 hours. Within these 12 hours, the staff off the mansion is killing the guests one by one. Your task is to prevent the murders, find out what is going on, and eventually break the loop.

Your presence is somewhat ghost-like. You cannot talk to or otherwise interact with other people (actually you have to hide from them), but you can investigate and manipulate objects as long as no one else is in the room. To prevent a murder, you first have to observe the actions of the characters, by peeking through keyholes into neighboring rooms, listening in on conversations, or hiding in cupboards. Once you understand the sequence of events, you need to find a way to break it, e.g. by manipulating a murder weapon before the killer picks it up. This creates puzzles which aren't overly complex, but imaginative and varied.

There are 6 of such murder cases to solve, with some of them having more than one murder to prevent. Saving a victim will give you access to another area of the mansion, where the next murder is taking place. You will also gain additional powers from each saved victim, which can be used to gain more information and reveal secrets throughout the mansion, giving you a reason to revisit areas you've already been to.

I found the puzzles and the mechanics of this game very engaging. Observation-based games [i]can[/i] easily become a bit boring due to the passivity of the main gameplay mechanic, and games with a time-loop mechanic [i]can[/i] easily get repetitive - but The Sexy Brutale never felt that way. I always found new interesting details. I felt that I was unraveling an intricately designed mystery, step by step, and the repetition of events affirmed me that my understanding of that mystery kept growing. (Also, once you prevented a murder, you don't have to repeat that ever again.)

I enjoyed the story and characters quite a lot. The characters are very distinct, you learn many little details about them, and the ending was appropriate and very touching.

The game's presentation is gorgeous. The graphics look splendid, and there is a lot of variation between the areas and rooms. The same goes for the music, especially the jazzy tones for the bar and casino evoke the atmosphere of such an upper-class establishment at some time in the last century perfectly. The sound design also integrates exceptionally well with the gameplay: sometimes you get audio cues from neighboring rooms, and certain events can be heard in the entire mansion. There is no voice acting, but I did not miss it.

For me, The Sexy Brutale was an amazing adventure, and I am really struggling to find something to criticize - apart from the godawful and completely misleading name. My biggest concern are probably the controls - keys cannot be rebound, and the control scheme assumes that the keys Z, X, 1, and 3 are close together since you have to press them frequently, often in time-critical moments. That's a problem for French, German, and Dvorak keyboards, and it's very disappointing that such an integral feature was overlooked in a game that is otherwise so finely polished.

Some players also complained about the game's length, but I think 20€ list price for a well-designed, highly polished game that took me 8 hours to solve and 10 hours to fully complete, are appropriate. Given that I have much less time now than I had 20 years ago, I actually appreciate games that pack high-quality content into an experience that can be fully had in a day or two. The Sexy Brutale fits that bill perfectly.

I recommend this game wholeheartedly to everyone who likes adventure games and murder mysteries, especially if you have an eye for details and like the setting.

You have to put ones and twos together to figure out what exactly is happening, and save a bunch of people from being murdered, but you're not allowed to interact with anybody directly. You can only effect change through actions that you do when nobody's around.

Everything in this game happens in about 10-ish minutes (12 "hours" in game time), but because everything happens in parallel, and you can't be everywhere at once, you basically keep playing these 12 "hours" over and over again, in different locations of this mansion. The art style... OH MY GOD the art style in this game. It is purely amazing, and the level of detail is just fantastic, i mean look at the screenshots.

Finally, the music is electro-swing, jazz, retro style music, which not only fits extremely well with the Gatsby-esque aestethic of the mansion, but is also in itself VERY good. You could just sit in front of your computer listening to this music for hours.

Seriously... buy... this ... game. It's SO good.

I bought it for £10 but it's worth the full price too.

32733475.review:
THIS REVIEW IS SPOILER FREE

***Please note this review comes from the point of view of a gamer who plays a lot of murder mystery games. A lot of the points I will talk about will pertain to this genre.***

[b] Verdict: Overall I would give the game 9/10. Sexy Brutale is a fantastic game that really adds a new twist and pushes the boundaries of the genre. I recommend this game and will continue supporting the developers should they make more games like this. [/b]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Play time

Play time was shorter than I would have liked. I beat the main story in 9 hours. I know part of this comes down to finances, developers, if you're reading this just know that I would be willing to pay more for a longer game. 

[*] Puzzle difficulty and Linearity of Puzzles

I am used to playing harder room escape games and the difficulty in this game was easy. It is set at a difficulty where anyone can solve it regardless of their experience in puzzle games. I personally wished it was harder (or at least an option to play at a higher difficulty) with less obvious hints. The puzzles are also quite linear, there are only a set number of items you can pick up in each area and it doesn't take much to figure out what to do. 

[*] Music Transition Between rooms

They are too abrupt and take away from the atmosphere of the game. 

[*] Buggy Controls

I had to fight with the controls a few times, there was some lag between my input and the display. Loading time between rooms is something I experienced somewhat frequently. That being said the game is playable and I did not experience any save file glitch. 

[/list]

Pros:
[list]

[*] Music

Music is absolutely amazing. I love jazz and this games SCREAMS 1920s to me. Music was tailored to each room and it fits the theme and art direction perfectly. A+.

[*] Story

If the story can move me then I think it's a story well done. I was definitely moved by the ending and it reminded me much of my favourite childhood game Majora's Mask. The dialogue between characters are fun and brings the characters to life. 

[*] Art Direction and Style

I loved the art direction with this game. It is unique, memorable, and really suits the character's personalities. The rooms are built to reflect their theme. I absolutely loved the Bar, Garden, Tank room, and insect room. 

[*] Game Play

Most of the games in this genre is text heavy with very little exploration options. This game is the opposite. It allows the players to move in 3D and piece together the story by themselves. I absolutely love this aspect of the game. It offers a fresh and interesting take on how games in this genre could be made. 

[/list]

Games that are similar and also available on steam: Danganronpa + Zero Escape Series

32709004.review:
If Clue and Majora's Mask had a child, it would be The Sexy Brutale.

You're Lafcadio, a guest in a lavish mansion where all guests are killed in one way or another via the hosts and servants. You quickly find yourself a pocketwatch that can rewind time and reset the day. If you've played Majora's Mask you know the drill, though, think of The Sexy Brutal as single day that goes by very quickly and you're in a dungeonous version of Clocktown though a bit bigger. There's 7 "missions," where you have to save a guest (or pair) but figuring out how to can be time consuming so there's a decent chunk  of content.

The Clue aspect is basically the film, but in reverse. First you have to find the person you need to save and how they're going to die and by whom, finding that out is the easy part. There's a minor stealth aspect in that you can't be in the same room as anyone else, everything goes dark an their mask will chase you down and out of the room. With that said, you can peer through keyholes and listen in on conversations to figure out where people have been and or what they're doing. You have to piece together all this information, in reverse, to find the key points where you mess with a plan or item that changes the course of time.

Once you save a guest you'll get a new power that will open up more of the mansion and the day will reset, all of the guests you save are still living out the same day, actually all guests are living the same day over and over and you can hear them all happening as well throughout the day. So for instance the first guest you save, the tutorial guest, is killed via a gunshot and at the same time everyday you'll hear that gunshot and you know he's died, yet again. Your task into the save them again, but to press forward.

At 5 hours I'm pretty much at the end of the game, I'm on last pair of guests I need to save before the final, single guest, so I can say I'm close to the end. It seems like the game can be done in under 8 hours easily which might seem short, but there's optional collectibles and the game has a great charm to it that makes it short and sweet so it adds a lot to the replayability for me.

So maybe, just like the game itself, I'll play it again... and again... and again... because it's really fun. Highly recommended.

[h1]Thoughts[/h1]
Games like this is why I love indie developers, they are the only ones brave enough to try different games and personally I had more fun in the 7 hours 100% completing this game than I have in more expensive AAA titles.

The game has an extremely cool premise where you have to stop a series of murders from happening by observing the murder take place and then tracing the steps back before the murder of both the victim and the perpetrator.  Its super clever and really fun to witness everything going on.  

The story is great, the mystery of why you are stopping these murders unravels as you get further on and by the end I felt completely satisfied, I wouldn’t change a thing in regards to the story.  Although the game has a puzzle tag the actual puzzle solving aspect isn't particularly difficult, it's more important to getting your timings right and observe the characters and how they interact with each other.

The design of the environment is truly great, the individual rooms are beautiful to look at and the whole place is amazing to wander around.  As you solve murders you gain new abilities that let you explore other parts of the mansion, it's always good to revisit earlier parts of the mansion with the new abilities.

The music is completely on point, it changes depending on the area you are in and appropriately sets up the mood for what is to happen next.  I particularly liked the music in the entrance of the casino :)

People say that the game is short but personally I think it's perfect in length, any more and it would be become stale, any less things would have felt rushed.  6-7 hours to complete and find all the secrets is perfect for me.

My only complaint with the game is there is little to no penalty for not being stealthy, I know it's not really a stealth game but being able to walk into a room whilst people are taking and just walk straight through and out the other side without any really impact to the story or characters is disappointing, personally I would have rather it changed the outcome of that particular day to which you need to rewind time to fix your mistake.

Overall though this game is exceptional, so far it’s the best game I've player this year (2017) and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

32025353.review:
[h1]Intryga prawie doskonała[/h1]
Niech nie zmyli Was słowo "Sexy" - w grze nie ma (niestety?) wielkich biustów i prężących swe wdzięki dziuń. To gra mądra, z dobrą historią i niezłym plot twistem na koniec. Nie jest to produkcja idealna technicznie, ale dzięki fabule można na pewne potknięcia przymknąć oko. Ale tylko jedno.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QYSLajUDGzw&list=PLW0kJB6mYV466SLETuQWD7o633A0Tb6QW

[h1]Przede wszystkim opowieść[/h1]
The Sexy Brutale to historia o winie, żalu i odkupieniu, czego nie widać od samego początku zabawy. Gracz spodziewa się, że Lafcadio Boone, nasz główny protagonista, jest tylko i wyłącznie wybawicielem. Ratujemy nim bowiem 9 ofiar właściciela tytułowego kasyna, Marquisa, który skazał swych gości na śmierć. Egzekutorami są jego służący, a my musimy pokrzyżować ich plany. Na szczęście chaos nie jest naszym wrogiem - nie ratujemy ich wszystkich naraz.

[h1]Dzień Świstaka[/h1]
Podstawową mechaniką rozgrywki jest pętla czasu, w której ugrzązł nasz bohater. Przeżywamy bowiem zawsze ten sam dzień, sobotę (dobrze, że nie poniedziałek, bo nikt by w to grać nie chciał!). Dzień trwa 12h - od południa do północy, później następuje reset. Możemy też zresetować dzień samodzielnie dzięki nieodzownemu gadżetowi Władcy Czasu - zegarkowi. Taki podręczny prototyp Tardis w wersji pre-alpha.

[h1]Prawie jak Sherlock[/h1]
Naszym podstawowym obowiązkiem jest śledzić poczynania postaci, którą aktualnie chcemy uratować. Jej ruch jest zawsze z góry ustalony, zachowanie daje nam sporo wskazówek, a rozmowy potrafią nakierować na odpowiednie rozwiązanie. Trzeba przyznać otwarcie, że nie ma w tej grze niczego zawiłego. Zagadki są proste, wręcz zbyt proste i nader oczywiste. Mógłbym się wręcz pokusić o stwierdzenie, że TSB nie wykorzystuje w pełni swojego potencjału. Ale może to dobrze, dzięki temu fabuła nie schodzi na drugi plan.

[h1]Supermoce i sekrety[/h1]
Niemal każda uratowana postać (a konkretniej jej maska) daje nam nową supermoc, która pozwala na coraz śmielszą i pełniejsza eksplorację wielopiętrowej rezydencji. Będziemy również korzystać z rozmaitych przedmiotów. Ale nie musimy skupiać się tylko na bohaterstwie, możemy skupić się na nieobligatoryjnych rzeczach: starać się zdobyć zaproszenia od każdego z gości (forma znajdźki, nierzadko całkiem sprytnie schowana) albo zebrać całą talię kart, co prowadzi do... pewnego sekretu. Sekretu, którego warto poznać!

[h1]Porysowane szkiełko zegarka[/h1]
Pod względem technicznym nie jest to idealna produkcja. Animacje postaci mogłyby wyglądać lepiej. Kamera czasami nie podąża za nami do sąsiednich pokojów. Czasami potrafi wręcz przyciąć, kiedy doładowuje kolejne segmenty planszy. Sytuacje ratuje historia, która - szczególnie pod koniec - potrafi zrobić niezły misz-masz w głowie. Po pierwszym przejściu gry nabawiłem się skrętu brwi i pomarszczenia czoła. Takiego obrotu spraw się nie spodziewałem...

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ Świetna historia
+ Zaskakujący plot twist na końcu
+ Masa znajdziek (52 karty, zaproszenia, opisy pomieszczeń)
+ Klimatyczna ścieżka dźwiękowa (♥ za muzykę z menu i piosenki Tequilli)
+ Wciągająca mechanika śledzenia postaci, odkrywania ich sekretów i poznawania historii
+ Niewymagający poziom trudności (co dla mnie osobiście byłoby minusem, ale z pozycji przeciętnego gracza i dla dobra fabuły, to był dobry ruch twórców)

[h1]Minusy[/h1]
– Nieprecyzyjne animacje postaci
– Sporadyczne zwiechy podczas ładowania lokacji i błędy kamery
– Nie do końca wykorzystany potencjał

[h1]Podsumowanie[/h1]
The Sexy Brutale na pewno ujmuje opowiadaną historią. Postaci, które ratujemy, nie są tylko pustymi pionkami. Mają swoją historię, osobowość i wszystkie są powiązane w jakiś sposób z rezydencją / kasynem. Końcówka gry zapewnia skręt zwojów mózgowych, skłania do analizy i własnych wniosków. Niewymagający poziom trudności zagadek nie powinien nikogo zablokować ani zrzucić fabuły na dalszy plan. Co prawda postacie mogłyby animować się płynniej i gra mogłaby być ciut lepiej dopracowana technicznie, ale to nadal całkiem satysfakcjonujący kawał dobrej rozrywki na kilka ładnych godzin. Przeszedłem ją na 100% i zdobyłem wszystkie osiągnięcia, a wierzcie mi na słowo(twórstwo) - robię to bardzo sporadycznie ;)

[h1]8+/10[/h1]

However, I won't recommend purchasing this at full price (hence the vote). Wait till a discount.

The main reason I say this is due to the length of this game - I completed the game in 6 hours (essentially one sitting). I consider myself to be a rather experienced player with these sort of games - I refer specifically games along the lines of Zero Escape, Danganronpa or Ace Attorney - and I found this game to be far too forgiving. With those other games I listed as examples, there are usually some mechanics to punish you (E.G. Zero Escape gives you bad ends, Ace Attorney has three strikes before the judge rekts you, same with Danganronpa). Here in this game... I'm not sure I really ever gotten myself in a situation where I might get a Game Over. Because there're no stakes, I'm just ramming my head through any obstacles that set itself in the way. 

Facing a connundrum that got you stuck? CLICK ALL THE THINGS! But then again there was almost nothing that got me stumped enough as to require me to get a time-out to think it over - again stuff that I sometimes had to do with the other games (not just those listed). Had the game forced me to do something like that, it'll have been a heck lot easier to recommend but since that's not the case, it's a real downer.

One of the game mechanics is that your character cannot be in the same room as any other character, you take "damage" if you are... The Sexy Brutale is a puzzle adventure game similar to Majora's Mask, although without the combat.  This is more the type of game where you need to use stealth to sneak around and find clues that will help you prevent the murders of your friends.  It takes place at a party in the titular casino mansion, where the staff murder all of the guests for some unknown reason.  As the protagonist, your job is to find out what this reason is, as well as locate Lucas, the mysterious owner of the casino who has not been seen recently.  To accomplish this, you must repeatedly play through the same day at the casino in a time loop not unlike those from Groundhog Day or Majora's Mask, rescuing each of the guests and inheriting their powers one by one as a result.  These powers allow for increased access to the rest of the mansion.

I found this style of gameplay to be simple, yet engaging at the same time; the puzzles weren't too hard, but still required me to think at least somewhat - especially due to the time factor.  Unfortunately, there were some occasional glitches with the graphics and controls that would cause the game to freeze up for a few seconds when entering a new area.  While this wasn't a game breaker, it was particularly annoying when I was short on time while trying to reach a certain destination - in a game like this, every second matters.  However, this was my only real complaint, as this game is generally very well put together.  I believe The Sexy Brutale's biggest strength is its story - specifically, its ending.  The entire game is rife with symbolism, which becomes even clearer at the mind-blowing conclusion.  I don't want to spoil any major plot details, so I'll just say the whole thing was brilliantly executed.  To top it all off, the graphical style and soundtrack were both charming and fit the game's wacky casino vibe perfectly.  It's all definitely worth your time, though it might be a good idea to wait for the sale.

The Sexy Brutale is sort of like Hitman in reverse, mixed with Majora's Mask. You've been invited to a masquerade party at the Sexy Brutale casino, only to be horrified when you realize that there's only one cards table and you're not very fond of roulette. They deliver another, slightly less traumatic but still shocking realization immediately afterwards: everyone in attendance is murdered in one day (about 10 minutes in real life). Finding the only cards table being permanently occupied by one of the other guests, you decide the only thing left to do is to rescue everyone so you can go find a different casino. 

The basic gameplay involves moving through the mansion and eavesdropping on the other guests, slowly piecing together what's happening and getting clues on how to save each guest. Saving a guest gives you a new ability, and each one helps you see the story a little better and access more of the mansion. Everything moves at the same pace throughout the mansion in real time, so you have to rewind to the beginning pretty often to see everyones' movements. It's more interesting to play than it is to read about, but if you enjoy point-and-click adventures you'll probably enjoy this. The story is interesting, and the art style manages to make horrific deaths look like cute doll scenes. If I had to complain about something, it would be the stealth aspect; essentially, your character can't be in the same room as another one, unless you were hiding in something beforehand (you can still eavesdrop through keyholes, though). If you do go into an occupied room, everything goes dark and the guest's mask starts to chase you, and I don't know what happens if it catches you because it never caught me but I imagine it's something bad, maybe even worse than being in the fanciest casino you've ever been in but only having roulette to play. It's not annoying enough to detract much from the game, but it also feels a little unnecessary, and I do think the game would be a little bit more fun if they had an option to let you wander around the guests and see the story better. But either way, the game is pretty fun, and an interesting way to put together an adventure game.

But seriously, only one card table? Does anyone actually like roulette?

[h1]Un Point&Click inventif qui pourrait intéresser pas mal de monde.[/h1]

Malgré un titre assez trompeur d'eroge déguisé en Visual Novel comme çà arrive beaucoup sur Steam, « The Sexy Brutale »(TSB) est bien un Point&Click(P&C) avec un concept un peu particulier et qui mérite votre curiosité.
Vous vous réveillez dans le manoir d'un marquis qui organise des festivités... mais vous allez vous rendre compte assez vite que les invités vont tous être assassiner dans les 12 heures. Une étrange femme en rouge va vous offrir le moyen de revivre ces 12 dernières heures bis repetitam pour vous donner les moyens d'empêcher çà. Qui est derrière tous ces meurtres et pourquoi ? Et d'abord c'est qui cette femme, et qu'est-ce que vous faîtes là ?... bah il va falloir terminer le jeu pour le découvrir !
Autre particularité, vous et toutes les personnes du manoir portent un masque. Le votre est assez particulier, parce qu'il vous empêche d'avoir une confrontation directe avec tout le monde(donc si on vous vois, c'est GAME OVER, pour faire simple...). Là encore, gne ?! réponse(ou pas) à la fin...
[u]Voilà donc les caractéristiques et la plus-value de TSB :[/u] 
-[b]les événements se déroule en temps réel[/b](si vous ne faites rien, les gens vont avoir un parcours prédéfini, à moins que vous ne changiez le cours des choses)
-[b]vous avez le moyen de rembobiner à tout moment[/b] pour revivre ces 12 heures depuis le début(ça se fera automatiquement si vous les dépasser)
-et pour ce faire, [b]va falloir la jouer un peu Metal Gear[/b], en espionnant aux portes , voir à se cacher dans des placards pour éviter d'être griller

Si çà peut paraître un peu déroutant, vous en faites pas, TSB est un [b]P&C vraiment pas compliqué [/b]: on a jamais besoin de plus de 2 objets dans l'inventaire pour changer le cours d'un meurtre([spoiler]certains objets restent dans votre inventaire, mais pour pouvoir débloquer plein de passage secrets comme dans un Metroid-Vania[/spoiler]). Pas non plus besoin de combiner des objets etc...
Y également rien de farfelu ou d'illogique dans les énigmes : observez, recherchez, analysez et vous trouverez la solution. Pas besoin d'avoir un bloc note et crayon pour déchiffrer des puzzles hyper cryptiques, c'est pas du tout ce genre de P&C.
[b]Parfait pour les néophytes, je pense que les originalités du titre pourrait proposer un moment relax et bénéfique pour les vétérans du genre[/b](dont je ne fais pas partie).

Y a également un petite originalité au niveau des contrôles, puisque, bien que très jouable au clavier, il est aussi penser pour la manette(un peu comme « Grim Fandango » mais en mieux fait et moins rigide). 
N.B. : j'ai une manette Xbox One, et j'ai eu aucun soucis de fonctionnement.

31571485.review:
The Sexy Brutale is a good game and you should buy it.

I know, I typically write longer more thoughtful introductions, I'll be critical over the things I hate and praise what I love, but to be completely honest, The Sexy Brutale is a near perfect experience from beginning to end. Because I'm a critic I'm still going to criticize it, but they're honestly small nitpicks. SB knows exactly what it wants to be as a murder mystery time traveling extravaganza and manages to pull it off.

Alright let's start with the complaints, only three this time. First off and the one that's probably going to get the most people: The Sexy Brutale eventually becomes a labrynth to explore. By the end of the game you have the ability to get around more quickly, but there's not really indication (from the map at least, there's pictures you can use but the end points from those are unknown unless you remember where they are) on where you end up when you fast travel this way. You kinda have to figure it out for yourself. You'll be looking at the map a lot, but again this is happening towards the end of the game where the whole hotel is opened up for you and you're allowed to freely explore. Second, for those completionists out there, the Playing Cards. They're put around in some obvious locations and then some much less obvious locations. You might still figure them all out but it'll take time. It just becomes a struggle when the game doesn't tell you what cards are missing. So it helps to explore thoroughly to begin with, looking at every object, and then make a second pass after you can fast travel to unlock and break things. Finally, from a gameplay standpoint, the stealth mechanic is pretty nonthreatening. You can easily enter rooms with other people, go through to the other side, and only take a very minor penalty. While being in the same room as someone else disables most of your options other than running, knowing that you can just move through rooms with people in them takes a lot of the danger from the game.

So what's good about this game? Pretty much everything. Music? Killer, wish they had the soundtrack to purchase other than getting the PS4 special edition. It's a great mix from creeping doom jazz to orchestrated cries to the void. Every murder mystery section of the hotel has its own variable mix to match what's currently going on and eventually you just sync with it. Gameplay? Nearly spotless. Minus that complaint I had about the stealth stuff, SB is well padded so you always feel the stress of time on you, doesn't feed you hints (well it does sometimes but you need to know where to look for the hints, and they may not seem like hints at first), humorous and atmopsheric dialogue makes redoing sections to find the solution actually a treat rather than a chore (barring a few situations), every puzzle can be solved with a little thinking and hunting and the game is more than willing to show you through its gameplay to do so. Controls? A little weird, but it works for the adventure game format. Controllers are better if you have one compared to mouse and keyboard. Graphics? Well, that's what drew me to this game to begin with, that squashed Viewtiful Joe / The Wonderful 101 art style for characters has a ton of charm and style and works well with the game. Plus so many things are well animated. The environments are diverse and intreging to explore... Goodness. Story? Oooh boy, loaded with nice little red herrings at the best times, you always feel like you're figuring things out and then it gives you a few hints to push you in another direction. Again, the dialogue here is great too.

I'm so happy to find amazing games that really pull me from beginning to end. The Sexy Brutale is such a game. If you dig stylish adventure games, there's a whole lot to like here. Plus the game sells normally at 20 US dollars for a game I'd probably spend at least 40 on. Yeah. The only reasons not to buy it are that you hate fun or want me to judge you. Or maybe you're a little squimish. That's possible too. Still, game good.

31568350.review:
I've spent under two hours in this game, but I'm leaving my review straight away because one thing's for sure: This game deserves far more attention.

The Groundhog Day concept in a video game is always something that's deserved a bit more exploration, and so far The Sexy Brutale executes on it in an excellent manner, with a very unique art style of its characters, very inventive level design, and just the right amount of information revealed over time to keep you interested.

Even after completing goals around each of the guests, I find myself eagerly rewinding to piece together parts of their day and conversations I had missed, and seeing their presence in all these different places, whispering to themselves in ways only my "Super Hearing" ability can pick up, offers an impressive amount of life to them.

While "You can miss a lot of things" is a pretty common field of game design now, the developers are good at knowing how to keep it from being busywork. Important information that could be easy to forget is marked on your map (eg "You now have the security codes to these three security cameras") as well as the known positions-per-time of each guest. The most the game will do to point out an objective is to give you a general idea of where to now explore, in the style of the new Zelda.

As I said, I'm still early in the game, and it's reported to be a slightly short game which is fine by me. The title may cause some people to raise an eyebrow, but this is a very unique and well-presented package.

EDIT: Ending comments sans-spoilers - This game is like the next Spec Ops: The Line for me in terms of literary value. I'd love to get a "book club" of people together and have them play the game together in one week, and then have them discuss "So what did X represent?" I probably would not have appreciated the ending much if people had just summarized it in a few sentences for me ("What? So....That's dumb!") but it's very well-presented, and ends up casting a whole new reflection on all the various seemingly unconnected elements of the game. I'd really recommend it for people who like great stories in games, albeit short ones.

31500103.review:
The Sexy Brutale is a time travelling "whodunit", where you (an old priest by the name of Lafcadio Boone) must use your newfound ability to rewind time in an attempt to stop the various murders of the Sexy Brutale's guests at the hands of the staff. Boone can't intervene in the murders directly, but he can manipulate the environment to stop them. When a guest is rescued, they'll bequeath you their mask, which will grant you a new ability or power. The game gives off a Majora's Mask kind of feel, with Boone reliving the same day over and over again while acquiring masks to grow in power and open the mansion for exploration, and I like the game, but I do have some thoughts on it...

Firstly, the murders themselves. They're creative and brutal (or should I say BRUTALE? Ahahahahaha oh god I'm so alone) but...they're rather easy to solve, and don't require a ton of exploration. I don't mean that there isn't exploration involved, but it will rarely take you outside of the area where the guest is getting murdered. Not only that, but when you have to rescue two guests at once, there's only one solution involved. I accidentally solved one of the murders, simply by wandering around and examining objects. 

Secondly, I think the game might have felt a little more organic if the mansion was more open. Most of the time, you focus on one guest, solve that, then move on to the next guest without really giving it a second thought, and just doing what the Bloody Girl tells you to do. I think letting the player explore more on their own would help the game feel a little bigger, and not quite so linear. But there isn't really anything wrong with this.

But those are really my biggest gripes with the game. The Sexy Brutale oozes personality, and most of the charm actually comes from watching the various staff and guests interact with one another. Each character has a unique personaility and you get to know them a little bit better by the end of your time travelling escapade. Each power you collect feels useful and opens up more of the mansion for exploration (Oh, on a slightly off-topic note, the story is ok. I was slightly disappointed by the ending, but I had fun overall).

The game is also loaded with with secrets and collectibles. There are 52 playing cards hidden around the mansion, and each guest has an invitation that explains a bit about their background and how they know the owner, the mysterious Marquis. 

Pros:
+ Characters have vibrant personailities
+ Murders are both creative and brutal
+There are loads of secrets and collectibles
+Great soundtrack
+Environments are interesting

Cons:
- Not a ton of exploration involved to solve murders
- Murders are kind of easy to solve
- Game is a little too linear 
- Ending is lackluster

Overall, I had fun with the Sexy Brutale, and I'm glad I played it. The game is good, but it lacks polish.

Instant buy after having seen about 2 minutes of Jim Sterling's video. The concept reminded me a lot of the DS game Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective, which I really enjoyed. (Seriously, if you liked this game, then try that one.) And I don't regret buying this game at full price, at all. This is actually the first time I've written a game review in my life, which should show just how much I like this game and want to make sure others know about it!

The time that I spent playing the game íncludes - apart from me gleefully exploring every little nook and cranny and watching all the scenes unfold in practically every single room - a couple of hours backtracking and looking for collectibles (which was slightly frustrating, see more under cons below).

PROS:
+ The art style is wonderful and unique, and I love the use of masks in the game. 
+ I absolutely love the music and how it's used: it creates a great sense of atmosphere and personality to the different locations, and it's used splendidly to create tension at just the right moments. I especially like the way the music changes depending on what's going on in the vicinity.
+ I personally love games that toy with time, but that's a preference that not everyone may share with me. 
+ The "puzzles" never frustrated me because they were based on observation rather than actual puzzle-solving. However, this isn't only a good thing. See more under cons below.
+ While the story concept (i.e. the reveal in the end) wasn't really new to me, it was interesting enough. Regarding the story throughout the game, I really like the concept of telling a story through bits and pieces like this: piecing it all together by watching what unfolds in all the rooms of the mansion, one scene at a time, and following it all in real time. The murders were clever and I greatly enjoyed watching them all (some more than others).
+ I guess it could have been a longer game, but seeing how much I loved it, I find it well worth the price even for just under 10 hours of gameplay.

CONS:
- The "puzzles" were not really puzzles and I personally found them a little too easy. Some of the puzzles I managed to accidentally solve while exploring the area, without even knowing what was going on, and that disappointed me, especially since I couldn't immediately do some of them over again (because the game forced me onwards). Furthermore, I would have preferred if there were different ways to approach every murder, instead of having only one way to solve them.
- The collectibles (playing cards) were mostly easy to find, and everytime I found one, the game told me which specific card it was. But with only one left that I hadn't found in the end, I was out of luck - there was no way to see which cards I had left. This forced me to look up a walkthrough, then meticulously going through basically the whole mansion to search through all the spots until I randomly happened upon one bookcase I hadn't checked. Tedious. (Also, the reward was slightly disappointing imo.)
- I would have liked having more options when it came to forwarding time, because as another review also mentioned, there were a few times where I had to just stand around and wait for things to happen.

TLDR; The Sexy Brutale is an awesome game with great atmosphere that nonetheless would have benefited from more complex, actual puzzles with different solutions. 9/10 from me.

The Sexy Brutale es un juego que rondaba mi radar desde que supe de él, y una vez jugado tengo que decir que mi experiencia ha sido muy satisfactoria.
La mecánica principal utiliza el tiempo para resolver una serie de crímenes que han tenido lugar en una excéntrica y gigantesca mansión que incorpora, entre otras estancias, un teatro y un casino. La trama tiene lugar en un solo día que se repite indefinidamente al llegar a la medianoche, al más puro estilo de Atrapado en el Tiempo. Frente a la acción y a la agilidad de reflejos prima la capacidad de observación y, en ocasiones, la paciencia (conseguir el retrato completo de uno de los asesinatos puede requerir repetir el día algunas veces, pero cada nuevo fragmento de información se sentía de lo más gratificante).

Otro punto fuerte que emparenta The Sexy Brutale con un género con el que a primera vista no parecería tener demasiado en común como son los Metroidvania es el desbloqueo de habilidades que te permiten acceder a otras habitaciones de la mansión. Las nuevas estancias tienen una cierta cohesión temática, dándole matices nuevos a la ambientación general.

Gameplay al margen, el juego destila estilazo. La atmósfera está muy bien conseguida, con guiños claros al steampunk, vudú, Lovecraft y en general a otros grandes del género de terror  de finales de S.XIX y principios del XX. The Sexy Brutale is a stylish murder-mystery, wrapped with point-and-click-esque puzzles (sans moon logic) and crossed with time travel.

The mansion is filled with over the top furnishings and rooms, both fantastic and occult. Quite fun to just explore, especially if you're a completionist who has to touch all the things. I loved following the different guests and staff around, watching them interact and eavesdropping on their conversations. The world is very well built and written, and the way the character paths weave together over the time line make the time travel quite satisfying. Most of the murders are creative and fun to foil, some are just weird.

There are a few rough patches. Some animation and audio transitions are jerky/sudden, and during my second play session some of the rooms took a noticable two or three seconds to load. The main character also controls poorly when near walls or obstacles, or even doors. Usually the game is generous enough with time that it doesn't cause you to fail, but it can be frustrating when you're trying to get to a closet to hide just before someone enters a room. May take you out of the experience for a moment, but the game will pull you right back in.

Played with a 360 controller. Beat the game 100% in a little over 8 hours. There's an alternate ending if you collect all the things. Decent length for the price, and doesn't overstay its welcome.
Recommended if you like a good story and some light puzzling.

Mais Brutale est vraiment sympa: vous êtes un personnage masqué coincé dans un manoir dans lequel des invités sont coincés aussi et se font tuer à tour de rôle. Votre rôle est d'empêcher que les meurtres se concrétisent.
Comment faire? Miracle, le jeu vous offre une montre qui vous permet de remonter le temps, permettant de recommencer la journée à l'infini. 


Chaque cible de meurtre se trouve dans une zone confinée du manoir composées de plusieurs pièces dans lesquelles se trouvent des objets qu'il va falloir combiner, associer ou bouger pour empêcher les meurtres, avant qu'il ait lieux, bien évidemment. Chaque victime sauvée porte un masque qu'elle vous offre. Chaque masque possède une capacité spéciale qui s'ajoutent à celles déjà possédées. Les possibilités de gameplay s'étoffent donc avec l'avancement du jeu.

Vous devez aussi écouter les conversations puisqu'elles peuvent vous fournir des informations utiles, ou suivre des personnages qui vous font découvrir des choses secrètes. Les informations que vous trouvez sont retenues automatiquement. Ainsi, si vous retenez un code, votre personnage s'en souviendra quand vous remonterez le temps. Les objets par contre disparaissent d'un "remontage" à l'autre.


Il s'agit d'un puzzle game en réalité, plus que d'un jeu d'aventure :  un objectif, des éléments a combiner pour l'atteindre. Empêchez un meurtre et vous passerez au suivant. 8 cibles.Si j'en crois mon avencement, je peux dire que le jeu n'est pas très long, entre 6 et 8 heures selon que vous galérez ou pas.

Il faut aimer les délires temporels du film "Groundhog Day" ou "un jour sans fin" dans nos contrées pour aimer ce jeu puisqu'il se base sur la répétition de la même journée encore et encore mais à chaque fois sous un angle différent car vous tentez autre chose à chaque fois. Le jeu                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         semble linéaire puisqu'il ne semble pas possible sur les 5 cibles que j'ai sauvées d'utiliser une autre méthode d'anti-meurtre.
Nous avons affaire à un jeu qui est d'une exemplarité au niveau du game design: toutes les pièces sont méticuleusement décorées pour donner  un style "art déco" au manoir du plus bel effet. On se croieraient dans une maison de poupée en train de regarder notre personnage en sauver d'autres. Les musiques sont excellentes également, totalement en adéquation avec le reste du jeu.

Tout en français, tout en humour noir subtil, ce cluedo inversé est une excellente surprise pour tout fan d'énigmes à base de paradoxes temporels  mais il reste simple, efficace, un poil court. 

7.5/10

After having pretty much finished the game (only lacking three collectibles), I'm ready to say that The Sexy Brutale is worth your time and money.
Despite a few little niggles here and there, like the clunky controls and lack of rebindable keys, a few minor bugs and the questionable necessity of having masks chase you around a room, the game still has a high degree of polish, a quite unique story that keeps you guessing and piecing clues together until the very end, some pretty good writing and a well-crafted atmosphere. 
Though obviously nothing is completely original, the setup for the story is fairly unique. I haven't seen anything quite like it before, though I'd bet my mother that there are at least a dozen good books taking their spin on the concept. Though the actual inevitable twist becomes somewhat predictable due to some heavy foreshadowing, the characters were entertaining and the creative and macabre death scenes were a lot of fun. While the game has the same sort of tryhard-y artsyness a lot of indiegames tend to go for, it has a lot of levity and charming writing and takes a lot of time indulging in its inherently fun and somewhat silly setting. This levity lead to me being much more absorbed in the story than I otherwise would've been, so I actually gave a crap by the end. So while it's not the greatest thing in the world, it's charming and doesn't take itself obnoxiously seriously, so it gets a big thumbs up from me.
Though I think some of the puzzles could've done with a bit more complexity, they were still tricky enough to keep me busy for a while. I'm not a big fan of puzzle games, so maybe their comparative simplicity was a bit of a blessing for people like me, but if you're really into the genre, they probably won't stimulate. But even then, there's still a very charming and creative mansion full of devious macabre secrets and amusing snippets of trivia to read up on as you pass through. 
Plus a killer soundtrack. I mean, sweet lords, those tunes are so taffing catchy, I can't even. This is one of the few times where I would not hesitate to spend the cash for the game's soundtrack, yet it's not even available! What a world we live in.
So on the whole, The Sexy Brutale is a very good game for people who are into this sort of thing. I doubt it will have a big mass appeal, but if you're the kind of person who enjoys spending a long evening getting absorbed in a slightly campy but charming setting, then I think you will enjoy your time with this one.
